title: Bridging Continuous-time LQR and Reinforcement Learning via Gradient Flow of the Bellman Error
authors: Armin Gießler, Albertus Johannes Malan, Sören Hohmann
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: In this paper, we present a novel method for computing the optimal feedback gain of the infinite-horizon Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR) problem via an ordinary differential equation. We introduce a novel continuous-time Bellman error, derived from the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation, which quantifies the suboptimality of stabilizing policies and is parametrized in terms of the feedback gain. We analyze its properties, including its effective domain, smoothness, and coerciveness, and show the existence of a unique stationary point within the stability region. Furthermore, we derive a closed-form gradient expression of the Bellman error that induces a gradient flow. This converges to the optimal feedback and generates a unique trajectory that exclusively comprises stabilizing feedback policies. Additionally, this work advances interesting connections between LQR theory and Reinforcement Learning (RL) by redefining suboptimality of the Algebraic Riccati Equation (ARE) as a Bellman error, adapting a state-independent formulation, and leveraging Lyapunov equations to overcome the infinite-horizon challenge. We validate our method in a simulation and compare it to the state of the art.

title: Bin-Picking With Category-Agnostic Segmentation for Unreliable Depth Scenarios
authors: Prem Raj, Lirong Xiang, Laxmidhar Behera, Tushar Sandhan
abstract: Robotic table-top grasping, a.k.a. bin-picking of unknown heterogeneous objects that are put together is a challenging problem due to clutter and uncertainty in depth-data. Out of many types of solutions to this problem, one uses a category-agnostic instance segmentation step before a grasp-planning step to segment out the object boundaries. Recently, various such methods have been proposed that use depth data produced from industrial-grade sensors, as input to their trained deep-learning models to reliably segment out the object instances in the cluttered bin. However, generally, with the commonly used commodity-grade depth sensors, the obtained depth data is noisy, particularly unreliable for non-opaque and thin objects. One other challenge could be time efficiency if the grasp-planning step needs to process each of the segmented objects in the grasp-planning step. To address these challenges, we propose a unified depth-independent CNN design that aims to co-learn category-agnostic instance segmentation, instance- wise grasp-confidence-scores (GCS), and monocular depth estimation, given the RGB image of the scene as the input. The estimated depth is used to detect collisions in grasp pose prediction and to transform the planner grasp pose to the 3D world coordinates. A novel GCS branch is developed into the instance-segmentation model to help filter the detected object instances based on their graspability, avoiding the need of processing each object for grasp planning. A custom-generated synthetic dataset is leveraged to train the proposed CNN architecture. We show through experimentation that our proposed bin-picking system can reliably pick various kinds of unknown objects (opaque, non-opaque, and thin objects) from a clutter of around 20-40 objects.

title: Gradient-Based Optimization for Linear Quantum Systems
authors: Yunyan Lee, Ian R. Petersen, Daoyi Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper presents a gradient-based optimization approach to solve optimal control problems in linear quantum systems. Utilizing an algebraic Lyapunov equation, we derive the partial derivatives of the cost function with respect to the steady-state covariance matrix. Furthermore, we formulate the gradient for the cost function when applied to a coherent quantum Linear Quadratic Gaussian (LQG) control problem. Through numerical simulations, we verify that our method effectively solves the LQG control problem.

title: When More Information Means Less: A Case Study in Asymmetric All-Pay Auctions
authors: Gilberto Díaz-García, Keith Paarporn, Jason R. Marden
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: Informational advantages represent a strategic opportunity in a large class of strategic games. In general, the level of uncertainty about the environment perceived by a competitor directly affects their performance. Therefore, having a clear understanding between uncertainty and performance has become a relevant research interest. Intuitively, it is expected that reducing uncertainty offers better guarantees in terms of the resulting performance. However, in this work, we provide a characterization that shows that reduced uncertainty does not guarantee better performance. Furthermore, it can be detrimental. We present such characterization in the context of asymmetric all-pay auctions, a standard model to study competitive interactions. By analyzing the resulting behavior of the competitors in terms of the Bayesian Nash equilibrium, we identify scenarios where acquiring better information not only does not affect the performance but also can be detrimental to it.

title: A RAG-Based Evaluation of Large Language Models for Financial Insights
authors: Chaitali Bhowmik, Monika Bansal, Nivedita Palia, Isha Gupta, Deepika Rawat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Innovations for Sustainable Solutions (ICDISS)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have transformed financial research by providing sophisticated analysis of complex textual data. This research examines the performance differences between GPT-4 and Gemini Pro and Claude and DeepSeek through a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) framework designed to interpret financial news. We built a Streamlit-based application through the integration of LangChain with HuggingFace embeddings and FAISS vector stores and Gemini APIs to create a system that mirrors real-world financial analysis requirements. Multiple metrics including contextual accuracy, relevance, factual consistency, latency and cost-efficiency serve as evaluation criteria for the models. The outcomes of other models are extrapolated from Gemini's complete implementation through extensive documentation and public benchmarks along with qualitative evaluation methods. The evaluation demonstrates that Gemini delivers better contextual relevancy along with faster inference speeds but GPT-4 demonstrates stronger coherence combined with more precise factual accuracy. This work presents actionable guidelines to choose appropriate LLMs for financial research alongside an analysis of how RAG systems boost model effectiveness.

title: A robust learning-based KKL observer for nonlinear systems
authors: Yangyi Zhao, Ruixuan Zhao, Boli Chen, Rui Wang, Peng Li
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper proposes a robust observer for nonlinear systems. A transformation is designed to convert the nonlinear system into a linear one, utilizing the Volterra integral operator to mitigate the effects of initialization errors. Neural network techniques are then applied to learn both the transformation and its inverse. As a result, the state variables of the nonlinear system can be accurately tracked using the estimated transformation, providing enhanced robustness against measurement noise and model uncertainty. Specifically, the proposed approach reduces the trade-off between convergence speed and noise immunity, which is often influenced by the choice of observer eigenvalue. The paper provides comprehensive error analysis and validation through simulations.

title: Towards a Reduced-Order Model for Anesthesia: Identification of Propofol-Remifentanil Effect as a Single Synergic Drug
authors: Marco Milanesi, Luca Consolini, Giulia Di Credico, Nicola Latronico, Mattia Laurini, Massimiliano Paltenghi, Michele Schiavo, Antonio Visioli
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: For personalized anesthesia, it is crucial to have accurate pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) models of anesthetic drugs. Typically, total intravenous anesthesia (TIVA) relies on the combined administration of propofol and remifentanil, which affect the bispectral index (BIS). This paper proposes a model reduction method that exploits the use of a fixed administration ratio between propofol and remifentanil, which is consistent with the clinical practice. Using a fourth-order ARX model, we estimate the effect-site concentration and fit the BIS response using a Hill function, thus implicitly considering the coadministration as if it was a single drug. The identification process is performed using a branch and bound approach, leveraging BIS data obtained during the induction of anesthesia. The identified model is then validated during the maintenance phase of anesthesia against models that are usually employed in clinical practice, where propofol and remifentanil are separately modeled. Results obtained on real BIS data show the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Enhancing Detection of Rare Cyber Threats Using GAN-Based Data Augmentation and Random Oversampling
authors: Nidhi Srivastav, Rajiv Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Innovations for Sustainable Solutions (ICDISS)
abstract: In the changing scenario of internet, the detection of cyber-attack have become important for safeguarding critical infrastructures, sensitive data, and organizational assets. Intrusion detection system can easily handle high frequency known attacks but the detection of low frequency attacks always presents a significant challenge. The low frequency attacks usually remain undetected, primarily due to imbalanced dataset. Traditional Machine learning Classifiers often underperform in identifying low frequency attacks when encounters imbalanced data distribution. This paper addresses the problem of imbalanced dataset and proposes its solution through application of Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) and Random Oversampling techniques. Adequate representation of minority classes is confirmed by Random Oversampling during model training, and GANs creates realistic synthetic samples of these classes. Proposed method incorporated both the techniques on a benchmark intrusion dataset UNR-IDD. Decision tree is selected as classifier and finds that through GAN low occurrence detection accuracy increases by 22% and with Random Oversampling detection accuracy of low occurrence attacks improves by 24%, without substantially raising the false positives.

title: Design and Implementation of a Highly Reliable Bridge Crane Control System
authors: Baoshu Liu, Xian Zhang, Jieqiang Liu, Hongliang Chen, Tiantian Li, Zike Wu
publish: 2025 2nd International Symposium on IoT and Intelligent Robotics (IoTIR)
abstract: In view of the requirements for high reliability and independent controllability of the control system of the bridge crane, this paper proposes an intelligent control scheme based on a domestic and independently controllable Programmable Logic Controller (PLC). This solution adopts domestic independently controllable PLC, multi-redundancy design, and speed closed-loop control strategy to build a highly reliable hardware platform, ensuring the control accuracy and dynamic stability of the system. Based on the domestic Kylin operating system, the safety management platform software is deployed to achieve real-time monitoring of the operation data of the bridge crane and fault alarm. To verify the system performance, load tests were respectively carried out under the PLC control mode and the emergency control mode, and the calculations were conducted through the Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) model. The results show that the MAPE of the operating speed of the bridge crane under the two modes is less than 1 %, which can meet the speed requirements of the control system of the bridge crane, and proves the scientificity and feasibility of this solution.

title: Semantic-Enhanced Image Object Detection in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Imagery
authors: Li Mai, Chen Dai, Rui Dai, Heyi Liu, Yeming Ding
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Dependable Systems and Their Applications (DSA)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have emerged as powerful and flexible platforms for a wide range of intelligent vision applications, including surveillance, search and rescue, environmental monitoring, and traffic analysis. At the core of these applications lies Visual Object Detection (VOD), which provides the fundamental capability of identifying and localizing objects of interest from aerial imagery. However, UAV-based visual detection remains a highly challenging problem due to factors such as drastic object scale variation, frequent occlusions, complex background clutter, and motion-induced distortions caused by dynamic aerial viewpoints. These challenges significantly degrade the robustness and generalization ability of existing detectors, particularly in small-object and high-altitude scenes. To overcome these limitations, this paper introduces a semantic-enhanced detection framework that integrates text-guided semantic priors into a Detection Transformer (DETR)-based architecture for UAV imagery. Leveraging multimodal learning, the proposed method incorporates high-level textual descriptions extracted via a pretrained vision-language model to enrich the visual feature representation and enhance discriminative capacity under challenging aerial conditions. Specifically, semantic embeddings from the text modality are fused with multiscale image features within the transformer encoder, enabling the detector to reason about object semantics, contextual relationships, and category dependencies in a unified end-toend manner. This multimodal enhancement enables the model to adapt more effectively to varying scenes and object scales without requiring extensive manual tuning. The proposed method is extensively validated on multiple benchmark UAV datasets, including VisDrone-2019 and UAVVaste, where it demonstrates superior detection performance, particularly in scenarios involving small objects and dense occlusions.

title: Ensure the Grid Interfaces and Payment Gateways Against Data Breach Attacks and Malware: Electric Vehicle Charging Station via Cybersecurity
authors: Paddabbai Chowdari Karanam, Karthikeyan Gurunathan, Ganesamoorthy Pandian, Ramanan Sathiaseelan, Koushik Lingam, Shiva Shankar Mummidi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Innovations for Sustainable Solutions (ICDISS)
abstract: Electric Vehicle Charging Stations (EVCS) deployment has been growing exponentially due to the fast integration of Electric Vehicles (EVs). These stations do not just handle the transfer of energy between the power grid and EVs, but also the delicate payment and user authentication procedures. Therefore, EVCS systems are becoming appealing to cyber attackers that want to take advantage of the existing vulnerabilities at grid interfaces and payment points. Privacy integrity and availability of such essential infrastructures are seriously threatened by data-leaking events, malware infection, ransomware and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks. “we have to have a substantial amount of control over the data, both on an information network and the physical operations themselves.” — these breaches can also result in theft or alteration of financial data, and mismanagement of charging operations, energy theft and potentially destabilization of the grid. This study prescribes a holistic cybersecurity architecture including solutions for both grid communication links, as well as payment processing subsystems at EVCS locations. The method combines multi-factor authentication, anti-malware, malware detection/prevention, and secure communication protocols for an end-to-end secure operation. To avoid unauthorized access or manipulation in the command of energy transfer, encrypted communication with mutual authentication is implemented on grid interfaces. Tokenization, two-factor authentication and process of identification and verification for advanced fraud detection are methods that protect the payment gateways and financial transactions. Malware is combated with constant system monitoring, signature-based scanning and AI-based anomaly detection that can detect zero-day threats by identifying when things are not operating as they should be. Also, the solution includes firmware integrity check to prevent malicious attacks and uses segmentation to separate the payment network from the grid control systems, allowing the two to be isolated from each other - thus reducing the likelihood of cross system compromise. The experimental results are obtained on a simulated EVCS network with real-world charging and payment transactions data for different cyberattack scenarios, such as man-in-the-middle, SQL injection, phishing-based credential theft, and malware injection. Experiments showed a 97.8 % detection rate, a 90 % of the payment fraud attempts prevented and a very low overhead <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(<50 \text{ms})$</tex> to normal charging or payment operations. The proposed framework provides a mechanism to make the infrastructure of EVCS a layered defensed system that can address operation and finance security issues together. The project increases trust in EV uptake, strengthens regulatory adherence to data protection laws, and erects a resilient shield against advancing cyber threats within an expanding smart mobility environment. This study illustrates that, in addition to safeguarding monetary transactions, active cybersecurity is necessary to ensure the security of the operation of power systems linked to EV charging systems.

title: Redundancy Check in Issue Reporting System
authors: Rongviriyapanish Songsakdi, Tunskul Gunpanich, Inhom Kanokpon
publish: 2025 20th International Joint Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Natural Language Processing (iSAI-NLP)
abstract: The Traffy Fondue application is a platform that allows citizens to report issues. However, many duplicate reports are submitted. This study proposes a method for detecting redundant issue reports by leveraging geolocation, issue type, and Thai text descriptions. A Thai NLP technique, TWSS, is enhanced through pre-processing strategies and the integration of geoqueries and geohashing to filter potential duplicates based on spatial proximity. Experimental results, using a dataset of 100 issue pairs, demonstrate that a pre-processing technique focusing on retaining specific Part-of-Speech categories yields the most effective results for computing semantic similarity between Thai sentences. Compared to two other techniques, this method achieves a high rate of accurate similarity checks for both identical and distinct issue pairs while optimizing processing time.

title: Bringing Explainability to Robo-Advisors: A Hybrid AI-Finance Decision Support System for Retail Portfolio Management
authors: Shaista Anwar, Harley Olaivar, Linda Rony
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Knowledge Economy (ICCIKE)
abstract: This study introduces an explainable AI-driven decision support system that enhances trust and transparency in robo-advisory portfolio recommendations for retail investors. Leveraging a synthetic dataset comprising diverse investor profiles characterized by income, risk tolerance, investment goals, and horizons the model categorizes users into risk segments and maps them to asset allocation strategies using historical return data from three ETFs: SPY, QQQ, and AGG. The system integrates SHAP (Shapley Additive Explanations) and decision trees to provide human-interpretable justifications for each recommendation. Results confirm that portfolio allocations align with established investment theory, with high risk profiles yielding higher returns alongside greater volatility. Statistical validation (p<0.001) supports a significant positive relationship between risk score and portfolio performance. The incorporation of explainability techniques improved clarity and user trust, demonstrating the practical value of transparent AI in digital wealth management and regulatory compliance.

title: Controlled Supermartingale Functions for Stochastic Differential Equations: Inference and Applications
authors: Masoumeh Ghanbarpour, Guillaume O. Berger, Sriram Sankaranarayanan
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: We study the problem of constructing controlled supermartingale functions to synthesize feedback laws that guarantee safety properties of stochastic differential equations (SDE) with control inputs. SDEs are widely used to model continuous time stochastic processes with applications ranging from financial markets to biology. In this paper, we extend classic notions from martingale theory for stochastic processes to prove that a given SDE will not exit a safe region over some finite time horizon with high probability. Our notion considers time-varying supermartingale functions that provide sharper probability bounds when compared to those that are time-independent. Furthermore, we study the controlled version of these supermartingales and the problem of synthesizing feedback control law that will maintain the state within a safe set with high probability over a given finite time horizon. We provide a projection-based algorithm for synthesizing polynomial, time-varying controlled supermartingales and corresponding feedback laws using sum-of-square (SOS) programming techniques. We implement our approach on some challenging numerical examples to demonstrate how it can synthesize control feedback laws that provide upper bounds on the probability of safety violations over a given time horizon.

title: Federated Learning with Explainable AI for Robust Skin Lesion Classification in Diverse Clinical Settings
authors: K Sridhar, Balajee Maram
publish: 2025 7th International Symposium on Advanced Electrical and Communication Technologies (ISAECT)
abstract: This research aims to develop a privacy-preserving, interpretable, and robust skin lesion classification system using Federated Learning (FL) combined with Explainable AI (XAI). The methodology uses the HAM10000 dataset, applies SMOTE for class balancing, extracts deep features with VGG16, ResNet50, and InceptionV3, fuses them with clinical metadata, and trains "Multilayer Perceptron" (MLP), "Feedforward Neural Network" (FNN), and "Deep Neural Network" (DNN) models with a soft voting ensemble. Results demonstrate that the ensemble model achieved the highest classification accuracy (95%) and improved generalization across minority classes. XAI techniques (LIME) provided visual explanations, enhancing clinical trust and interpretability. This work shows that integrating FL and XAI ensures privacy, improves performance, and supports reliable AI-driven decision-making.

title: Taming High-Dimensional Dynamics: Learning Optimal Projections onto Spectral Submanifolds
authors: Hugo Buurmeijer, Luis Pabon, John Irvin Alora, Roshan S. Kaundinya, George Haller, Marco Pavone
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: High-dimensional nonlinear systems pose considerable challenges for modeling and control across many domains, from fluid mechanics to advanced robotics. Such systems are typically approximated with reduced-order models, which often rely on orthogonal projections, a simplification that may lead to large prediction errors. In this work, we derive optimality of fiber-aligned projections onto spectral submanifolds, preserving the nonlinear geometric structure and minimizing long-term prediction error. We propose a data-driven procedure to learn these projections from trajectories and demonstrate its effectiveness through a 180-dimensional robotic system. Our reduced-order models achieve up to fivefold improvement in trajectory tracking accuracy under model predictive control compared to the state of the art.

title: TL-NBEATS: An Interpretable Transfer Learning Framework for Forecasting Sri Lankan Tourist Arrivals Under Structural Breaks
authors: W.W.M.S. Fernando, D.D.A. Arthanayake, M.W.P. Maduranga
publish: 2025 9th SLAAI International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (SLAAI-ICAI)
abstract: Accurate forecasting of tourist arrivals in Sri Lanka, a vital economic sector, is challenged by significant volatility and structural breaks, particularly the profound COVID-19 pandemic. This research develops and evaluates a comprehensive deep learning pipeline for predicting univariate monthly tourist arrivals to support strategic planning. The paper’s contribution is threefold: first, we propose an interpretable N-BEATS model that utilizes a novel two-stage transfer learning strategy to explicitly manage the COVID-19 structural break. An ablation study demonstrates that our transfer learning methodology significantly reduces forecast error by 59.7% (RMSE: 42,252 to 17,007) compared to standard end-to-end training ($\mathrm{p}=0.027$, Diebold-Mariano test). Second, we rigorously benchmark this model against a strong Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) baseline, providing comprehensive comparative analysis across 13 key performance metrics and statistical tests. The proposed N-BEATS model achieves consistent improvements over LSTM across all metrics ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}} \boldsymbol{:} \mathbf{0. 8 6 6}$ vs $\mathbf{0. 8 2 4}$; MAPE: $\mathbf{7. 5 5 \%}$ vs $\mathbf{9. 7 3 \%}$; RMSE: 17,007 vs 19,470) while providing interpretable trend-seasonality decomposition unavailable in black-box LSTM architectures. Third, we provide a completely replicable implementation to facilitate widespread real-world applications. Beyond accuracy gains, this work critically contributes a validated methodological framework for effectively handling structural breaks in tourism forecasting, offering a vital case study for time series prediction in volatile contexts.

title: Analysis of Machine Learning and Deep Learning Approaches for Stock Market Time Series Forecasting
authors: Ajitkumar Kadam, Kavitha Rani P
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Knowledge Economy (ICCIKE)
abstract: This paper presents a PRISMA-grounded survey of machine learning and deep learning methods for stockmarket time-series forecasting. Although research in this area has accelerated, reproducible evaluation, leak-proof validation, and cost-aware deployment are inconsistently addressed, limiting practical impact. A dual-reviewer Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) protocol was applied across IEEE Xplore, Scopus, Web of Science, SSRN, and the ACM Digital Library to screen studies on equity forecasting using Open-High-Low-Close-Volume (OHLCV), returns, and volatility. The review synthesizes model families and features, normalizes evaluation practices around rolling-origin, walk-forward, and embargoed splits, and appraises deployment realism via transaction costs, slippage, order execution logic, latency, and capacity constraints. Outcomes highlight recurrent risks: split leakage, lookahead in indicator computation, weak or absent baselines, omission of costs, and sparse external or cross-market tests; under these controls, deep learning often fails to dominate simpler machine learning alternatives, and feature engineering with rigorous leakage control frequently determines success. The study standardizes primary metrics including Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), and directional accuracy, and recommends statistical testing via the Superior Predictive Ability (SPA) test with False Discovery Rate (FDR) correction. The contribution is a taxonomy linking methods, markets, and evaluation outcomes, together with a deploymentaware reporting framework that specifies leakage controls, cost modeling, latency, and capacity indicators. Transaction costs reshape apparent performance. The guidance supports researchers and practitioners in designing comparable, reproducible studies and in selecting methods suited to realistic trading constraints.

title: Tube-Based robust nonlinear model predictive control of anaerobic co-digestion
authors: Davide Carecci, Laurent Dewasme, Alessio La Bella, Gianni Ferretti, Alain Vande Wouwer
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: To match the growing demand for bio-methane production, anaerobic digesters need to embrace the co-digestion of different feedstocks; in addition, to improve the techno-economic performance, an optimal and time-varying adaptation of the input diet is required. These operation modes constitute a very hard challenge for the limited instrumentation and control equipment typically installed aboard full-scale plants. A model-based predictive approach may be able to handle such control problem, but the identification of reliable predictive models is limited by the low information content typical of the data available from full-scale plants’ operations, which entail high parametric uncertainty. In this work, the application of a tube-based robust nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC) is proposed to regulate bio-methane production over a period of diet change in time, while warranting safe operation and dealing with uncertainties. In view of its upcoming validation on a true small pilot-scale plant, the NMPC capabilities are assessed via numerical simulations designed to resemble as much as possible the experimental setup, along with some practical final considerations.

title: A Comprehensive Review on Security-Enhanced User Experience Model for E-learning systems
authors: Pasindu Udugahapattuwa, Shantha Fernando
publish: 2025 9th SLAAI International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (SLAAI-ICAI)
abstract: The rapid proliferation of E-learning platforms has transformed educational delivery across academic institutions and corporate training environments, offering unprecedented accessibility while introducing complex security challenges that must be addressed without compromising user experience. Current E-learning systems face significant vulnerabilities, including unauthorized access, data breaches, identity fraud, and compromised assessment integrity, collectively threatening user privacy and institutional credibility. Existing security implementations often create friction through cumbersome authentication procedures, complex password requirements, and intrusive monitoring systems that negatively impact user satisfaction and learning outcomes. The significant research gap addressed in this comprehensive review is understanding the optimal balance between robust security implementations and seamless user experience in E-learning environments, where traditional security measures frequently conflict with usability principles. This study proposes the Security-Enhanced User Experience Model for E-learning (SEUEM) systems, a conceptual framework integrating advanced security constructs, including biometric authentication, machine learning-based trust models, and blockchain credentialing into established user experience frameworks. Key contributions include adaptive authentication mechanisms that adjust security levels based on contextual risk assessment, frictionless biometric systems enhancing both security and user convenience, and blockchain-based credentialing systems ensuring tamper-proof certification while maintaining accessibility. Future research directions encompass quantifying the cognitive load of multifactor authentication protocols, balancing surveillance with learner autonomy and ethics, incorporating accessibility in biometric systems, and addressing blockchain credentialing scalability under high-volume assessment conditions.

title: Enhancing SQL Query Learning Using Chatbot with NLP: A Methodical Review
authors: Bahasuru Nayanakantha, M. A. P. P. Dayarathne, R. L. W. Koggalage
publish: 2025 9th SLAAI International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (SLAAI-ICAI)
abstract: This systematic review investigates how Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques, particularly chatbot-based and text-to-SQL systems, have been applied to enhance SQL learning. Following the PRISMA framework, 26 peer-reviewed studies published between 2018 and 2025 were analyzed to identify trends, pedagogical outcomes, and research gaps. Unlike previous surveys that primarily focused on algorithmic performance, this review uniquely emphasizes the pedagogical integration of AI-driven SQL tutoring tools. A two-dimensional taxonomy was developed to categorize reviewed studies based on NLP technique type (rule-based, Seq2Seq, and Large Language Model) and application focus (educational or general-purpose). The synthesis reveals that LLM-based systems dominate recent developments, offering enhanced contextual understanding and adaptive feedback. However, challenges remain regarding scalability, error interpretation, and alignment with instructional design principles. Findings indicate that NLPpowered chatbots significantly improve learner engagement, motivation, and conceptual understanding by enabling natural language query generation and real-time feedback. Nonetheless, pedagogical grounding and long-term learning evaluation are limited. The review identifies key future directions, including pedagogically informed feedback mechanisms, scalable model design, and integration into learning management systems. Overall, this review contributes a structured synthesis and taxonomy that links technical progress with educational theory, providing a foundation for developing intelligent, theory-driven SQL tutoring systems that bridge language, logic, and learning.

title: An Optimistic Gradient Tracking Method for Distributed Minimax Optimization
authors: Yan Huang, Jinming Xu, Jiming Chen, Karl Henrik Johansson
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper studies the distributed minimax optimization problem over networks. To enhance convergence performance, we propose a distributed optimistic gradient tracking method, termed DOGT, which solves a surrogate function that captures the similarity between local objective functions to approximate a centralized optimistic approach locally. Leveraging a Lyapunov-based analysis, we prove that DOGT achieves linear convergence to the optimal solution for strongly convex-strongly concave objective functions while remaining robust to the heterogeneity among them. Moreover, by integrating an accelerated consensus protocol, the accelerated DOGT (ADOGT) algorithm achieves an optimal convergence rate of $\mathcal{O}\left( {\kappa \log \left( {{ \in ^{ - 1}}} \right)} \right)$ and communication complexity of $\mathcal{O}\left( {\kappa \log \left( {{ \in ^{ - 1}}} \right)/\sqrt {1 - \sqrt {{\rho _W}} } } \right)$ for a suboptimality level of ϵ> 0, where κ is the condition number of the objective function and ρ<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">W</inf> is the spectrum gap of the network. Numerical experiments illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms.

title: A Graph-Based Approach to Anomaly Detection in Windows Event Logs for Enhanced Digital Forensics and Incident Response (DFIR)
authors: Saad Alzubari, Shahnawaz Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Emerging Trends in Engineering and Computing (ETECOM)
abstract: The immense volume and semi-structured complexity of Windows Event Logs (WEL) make manual analysis exceptionally difficult, often causing critical delays in incident response and allowing sophisticated cyber threats to go undetected as some anomalies and threats are recorded as benign in WEL like Privilege Escalation attempts and Log Clearing attempts. This research addresses the limitations of manual and conventional analysis by investigating the efficacy of machine learning, particularly Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), for automated anomaly detection. A quantitative experimental methodology was employed, wherein a controlled lab environment was established to simulate three common and critical attack techniques: Brute Force, Privilege Escalation (specifically UAC Bypass), and Log Clearing. The resulting dataset underwent rigorous preprocessing, including feature engineering, dimensionality reduction via PCA, and class balancing using the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE). A GNN model was developed to capture the complex relational structure inherent in log data and its performance was benchmarked against a suite of traditional machine learning classifiers. The results demonstrate the clear superiority of the graph-based approach, with the GNN achieving an accuracy of 96.56% and an F1-score of 97.93%, significantly outperforming the next-best model, Random Forest (92.04% accuracy). The findings confirm that by modeling the contextual relationships between events, rather than treating them as isolated data points, GNNs provide a more robust and accurate method for identifying malicious activities. Key contributions of this research include the generation of a new, high-fidelity labeled dataset based on realistic attack simulations and empirical evidence that graph-based models can substantially enhance the speed and precision of DFIR processes, offering a powerful tool for modern cybersecurity operations.

title: Hyperbolic Functions and the Modulating Function Method
authors: Davi G. Accioli, Jerome Jouffroy
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: The modulating function method is an integral transform method that has been used for state and parameter estimation of lumped systems, as well as estimation of distributed and fractional-order systems. The kernel of the modulation operator for input-output systems is called the modulating function, having the resulting filter characteristics dictated by this choice. Since this selection is crucial in the filter design process, different functions have been proposed over the years, until a different approach was introduced: obtaining the modulating function as a solution to an auxiliary problem. This approach is, in fact, common within mathematics, and well-known functions, such as hyperbolic sine and cosine, are obtained as the solution to a particular auxiliary system. Intriguingly, hyperbolic functions generate 4 new types of modulating functions in a simple manner. Moreover, 12 types of mixed hyperbolic modulating functions are obtained by using different hyperbolic functions to satisfy the boundary conditions. Lastly, an application example shows that hyperbolic modulating functions can display significantly lower bias than polynomial modulating functions.

title: Classrooms Without Borders: Charting Innovative Pathways for Artificial Intelligence in Education
authors: Renato R. Maaliw, Jovela I. Peñaojas, Marissa C. Esperal, Ricaryl Catherine P. Cruz, Shiela M. Manzanilla, Gillian Portia P. Dimaranan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Emerging Trends in Engineering and Computing (ETECOM)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming and reshaping the educational domain. As educators seek innovative approaches to improve student outcomes, AI’s capacity to tailor resources and predict performance makes it indispensable for classrooms. Existing research focuses on narrow aspects, overlooking a holistic perspective that embraces teacher training needs, ethical considerations, and policy frameworks. This review aims to investigate how AI-driven solutions can be effectively integrated into teaching. Using a narrative method, studies are synthesized to illustrate its successes and emerging gaps. While it can significantly enrich pedagogical processes, responsible implementation, stakeholder collaboration, and ethical awareness remain essential for sustained impact. Our findings reveal notable gains in personalization and efficiency yet underline persistent hurdles in data privacy, algorithmic bias, and teacher readiness. By emphasizing trends and shortfalls, this review contributes to a multidimensional understanding of AI’s potential and harnessing it judiciously for a more equitable learning outcome.

title: NISE-PE Constraint: Data-Driven Predictive Control with Persistence of Excitation
authors: Lucca Heinze Faro, Yuanbo Nie, Paul Trodden
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: Persistence of excitation (PE) is an important requirement for the successful operation of data-driven predictive control, as it ensures that the input–output data contains sufficient information about the underlying system dynamics. Nonetheless, this property is usually assumed rather than guaranteed. This paper introduces a novel data-driven predictive control formulation that maintains PE. The technical development that allows this is the characterisation of the nonexciting input set (NIS), i.e., the set of inputs that lead to loss of PE, and the consequent derivation of a pair of disjoint, linear inequality constraints on the input, termed NIS exclusion PE (NISE–PE) constraint, that, if satisfied, maintain PE. When used in a predictive control formulation, these constraints lead to a mixed-integer optimal control problem with a single binary variable or, equivalently, a pair of disjoint quadratic programming problems that can be efficiently and reliably solved. Numerical examples show how these constraints are able to maintain PE during the controller’s operation, resulting in improved performance over conventional approaches for both time-invariant and time-varying systems.

title: Fine-Tuning Vision Transformers for Real-Time Pest Classification in Urban Environments
authors: C.N. Hettiarachchi, R.G.N. Meegama
publish: 2025 9th SLAAI International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (SLAAI-ICAI)
abstract: The rapid growth of pest populations in urban environments leads to high risks for health, food security, and urban infrastructure. Pest identification must be accurate to take effective measures to control the pests. Urban pests, however, tend to have visual traits that match the background, thus making it difficult to spot them due to the background clutter, visual obstruction and morphological similarity among the species. This study investigates the use of fine-tuned Vision Transformers (ViTs) for urban pest classification and benchmarks their performance against a conventional ResNet-50 convolutional neural network. A comprehensive dataset of 25,990 images of 19 pest species was captured that include various types of real-world settings. Both models were trained under identical pre-processing and augmentation settings. Model performance was evaluated using precision, accuracy, recall, and F1-score and finally validated by independent two-sample t-tests. This finding indicated that ViT achieved a test accuracy of 97.86%, outperforming ResNet50 ‘s accuracy of 88.38%. Moreover, ViT attained enhanced mean precision (0.977 vs. 0.884), recall (0.979 vs. 0.891), and F1score (0.979 vs. 0.881), with all enhancements being statistically significant ($p\lt0.05$). These findings confirm that there are high accuracy and generalization of ViTs, but also demonstrate increased resistance to visual clutter and occlusion. The present research offers a statistically valid analysis of ViT performance in urban pest classification and thus demonstrates the possibility of deploying it in real-time in smart pest management systems.

title: A Guided Retraining Strategy For Safe ReLU Neural Network Controllers Of Linear Systems
authors: João Gabriel Zago, Giuseppe Notarstefano, Eduardo Camponogara
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper considers a ReLU neural network approximation for an optimization-based controller of a discrete Linear Time Invariant (LTI) system. If trained in a standard way, a data-driven controller based on neural networks may violate safety constraints or require many training samples to avoid violation. We propose a novel sampling approach, based on a proper reachability analysis for ReLU networks, that results in an efficient retraining of the neural network and guarantees constraint satisfaction. We show the effectiveness of the proposed strategy by providing numerical results on a neural network trained to approximate a Model Predictive Controller (MPC). Compared to a random sampling, our approach achieves safety with a relatively small number of samples thanks to an ad-hoc resampling in suitable regions of the state space.

title: Computer Vision Based Approach to Work Force Tracking for Safety Compliance Monitoring
authors: K. T. A. R. Hansamal, S. Shaarukshan, S. K. Sakinu, K. Abinan, U. Matara Arachchi, I. T. S. Piyatilake
publish: 2025 9th SLAAI International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (SLAAI-ICAI)
abstract: Ensuring construction site safety through continuous monitoring of worker activity and personal protective equipment (PPE) compliance remains a significant challenge. This paper presents a vision-based system for persistent worker tracking and automated PPE detection using deep learning and computer vision techniques. Real-time detection of PPE compliance, specifically safety helmets and vests, is achieved using the You Only Look Once (YOLOv8) object detection model. To maintain long-term identity tracking across multiple sessions and camera views, an OmniScale ReIdentification (ReID) model is integrated with a curated reference-image-set of workers. This enables the system to associate detected individuals with named profiles, allowing precise violation attribution and temporal tracking beyond single-day monitoring. The reference-image-set enhances the reliability of person matching and ensures that compliance logs are consistently linked to the correct worker. Evaluation results show high accuracy in PPE violation detection and good Rankn CMC scores for identity consistency, supporting proactive safety enforcement and comprehensive violation reporting in dynamic construction environments.

title: Image-Based Autism Spectrum Disorder and Deep Learning: A Review Paper
authors: H.A. Dimuthu Maduranga Arachchi, H.P. Dimuth Prasanna Pathirana, G.D. Samarasinghe
publish: 2025 9th SLAAI International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (SLAAI-ICAI)
abstract: Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a neurodevelopmental condition characterized by social, communication, and behavioral challenges, where early detection is crucial for timely intervention. Current diagnostic methods include manual approaches (observation or caregiver interviews), which are subjective and time-consuming, and automated techniques leveraging machine learning (ML) and deep learning (DL) for image/video analysis. This review examines DL-based ASD diagnosis using image/video data, covering studies published from 2023 to July 2025 from PubMed and Scopus, following PRISMA guidelines. Among 17 analyzed studies, we categorize research based on input features, review public/private ASD datasets, and discuss effective rehabilitation strategies. The review highlights challenges in automated ASD detection and classification while emphasizing DL’s growing role in enabling precise, cost-effective diagnosis. Our review and future research directions aim to assist researchers, therapists, and psychologists in advancing ASD screening and monitoring through DL-driven image/video analysis.

title: Experimental Implementation and Validation of Predictor-Based CACC for Vehicular Platoons With Distinct Actuation Delays
authors: Amirhossein Samii, Redmer De Haan, Nikolaos Bekiaris-Liberis
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: We provide experimental validation, in a pair of vehicles, of a recently introduced predictor-based cooperative adaptive cruise control (CACC) design, developed for achieving delay compensation in heterogeneous vehicular platoons subject to long actuation delays that may be distinct for each individual vehicle. We provide the explicit formulae of the control design that is implemented, accounting for the effect of zero-order hold and sampled measurements; as well as we obtain vehicle and string stability conditions numerically, via derivation of the transfer functions relating the speeds of pairs of consecutive vehicles. We also present consistent simulation results for a platoon with a larger number of vehicles, under digital implementation of the controller. Both the simulation and experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the predictor-based CACC design in guaranteeing individual vehicle stability, string stability, and tracking, despite long/distinct actuation delays.

title: Integrating Digital Twin and Random Survival Forests for Predicting Fatigue Behavior in Materials
authors: B. Venkata Jayani, Gnanajeyaraman Rajaram
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Knowledge Economy (ICCIKE)
abstract: Fatigue failure poses a significant threat to the safety and reliability of mechanical systems, often leading to catastrophic and unpredictable outcomes. Traditional deterministic models and reactive maintenance strategies are inadequate for modern industrial applications, where assets are expected to operate continuously under varying loads and environmental conditions. The challenge is compounded by the prevalence of censored data, where the exact time of failure is unknown for many components. To address this critical need, this paper proposes a novel framework for a digital twin dedicated to prognostics and health management (PHM). Our methodology leverages the power of survival analysis, a statistical branch uniquely suited to modeling time-to-event data with censoring. We utilize a Random Survival Forest model to establish a probabilistic relationship between operational parameters and a component's remaining useful life (RUL). The model is trained on a comprehensive dataset, integrating physically-informed features to enhance its predictive capability. Through a rigorous cross-validation process, we demonstrate the robustness and generalization of our approach. The framework's performance is evaluated using key metrics that assess both its ability to rank components by their failure risk and the accuracy of its probabilistic predictions over time. The results indicate that the developed digital twin possesses an exceptional ability to differentiate between high and low-risk components and provides highly reliable survival probability curves. This capability enables a significant paradigm shift from reactive to proactive maintenance, allowing for the optimization of asset management, the reduction of unplanned downtime, and a marked improvement in system safety. The proposed framework provides a compelling and generalizable solution for building effective digital twins that can guide decision-making in real-world engineering applications.

title:
Analysis and Synthesis for the ℒ
                    <sub>∞/2</sub>
                    -Induced Norms of Sampled-Data Systems via Differential Linear Matrix Inequality Approach
authors: Hae Yeon Park, Hyung Tae Choi, Jung Hoon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper is concerned with the analysis and controller synthesis for the ${{\mathcal{L}}_{\infty /2}}$-induced norms of sampled-data systems through the differential linear matrix inequality (DLMI)-based approach, in which two types of ${{\mathcal{L}}_\infty }$ norms are taken for the output as the temporal supremum under the spatial ∞-norm and 2-norm, and the ${{\mathcal{L}}_2}$ norm is considered for the input as the temporal 2-norm under the spatial 2-norm. We first introduce a hybrid linear system (HLS) representation to describe the input/output behavior of sampled-data systems. Based on this HLS representation, we next establish some DLMI conditions that ensure that the ${{\mathcal{L}}_{\infty /2}}$-induced norms are less than a pregiven γ (> 0). These conditions lead to controller synthesis procedures for ensuring that the resulting sampled-data systems are asymptotically stable and their ${{\mathcal{L}}_{\infty /2}}$-induced norms are less than a pregiven γ (> 0). Finally, some numerical examples are given to validate the theoretical results developed in this paper.

title: Influence of Individual Image on Team Dynamics in IT-Related Undergraduate Projects: Investigating the Hue Effect
authors: B.M.G.S.T.S.K. Wickramasinghe, K.D.B. Aratthanage, W.A.L.P. Fernando, N.G.P.R. Premachandra, J. Kirushika, T.D.T. Madhushika
publish: 2025 9th SLAAI International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (SLAAI-ICAI)
abstract: Teamwork is integral to software engineering education, yet team-based assessments may be distorted by cognitive biases such as the “hue effect,” where traits like confidence, communication fluency, or prior success disproportionately influence perceptions of competence. This study investigates the prevalence and impact of the hue effect within undergraduate software engineering teams in Sri Lanka, focusing on its influence on peer and instructor evaluations, leadership selection, and role distribution. Using a quantitative, cross-sectional survey, data were collected from 192 undergraduates with prior group project experience via a structured, five-section questionnaire. Responses were analyzed using descriptive statistics and unsupervised machine learning (K-Means clustering) to identify underlying patterns in perceptions of bias, teamwork dynamics, and self-awareness. The Elbow Method and Silhouette Analysis identified three distinct clusters: (1) students with balanced perceptions of fairness and teamwork, (2) students more sensitive to bias and undervaluation, and (3) students demonstrating heightened selfreflection and awareness of their team role and influence. Analysis of mitigation strategies revealed strong student support for structured rubrics and moderate support for anonymous peer evaluations, alongside preferences for instructor-led monitoring, role rotation, and bias-awareness training. The findings highlight that evaluation fairness in team projects is shaped not only by technical contribution but also by interpersonal impressions, with implications for inclusivity, motivation, and equitable skill recognition. This research contributes context-specific evidence from South Asia, offering actionable recommendations for academic policy, including structured evaluation criteria, partial anonymity in peer reviews, and targeted interventions to address perception-based bias in collaborative learning environments.

title: A Deep Reinforcement Learning Framework for Dynamic Smart Grid Optimization in Urban Environments
authors: Archanaa CK, Gnanajeyaraman Rajaram
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Knowledge Economy (ICCIKE)
abstract: Growing city populations and the influx of unpredictable renewable energy sources are placing unprecedented strain on today's power grids. Traditional control systems are often ill equipped to handle the complex, constantly changing conditions of a modern smart grid. This paper introduces a new framework that uses Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) to automate and optimize smart grid operations. At the core of our approach is a Deep Q Network (DQN) agent, which learns to make intelligent, real-time decisions about managing energy flow choosing whether to store, release, or conserve power. The agent was trained within a simulated urban environment, driven by a dataset reflecting hourly changes in power demand and green energy production. Its objective was to master a policy that maximizes a custom reward signal, carefully designed to weigh the competing goals of grid stability and overall energy efficiency. Our findings confirm the viability of using DRL as a powerful tool for autonomous grid management, contributing to the development of more reliable and sustainable energy infrastructure for future cities.

title: RIS-Enhanced Hybrid THz/RF Systems for 6 G Networks Over Generalized Fading
authors: Rithwik Premanand, Narendra Vishwakarma, Ranjan Singh, A. S. Madhukumar
abstract: Terahertz (THz) communication, a key enabler for 6 G networks, suffers from high path loss and limited coverage. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a RIS-assisted hybrid THz/RF architecture that integrates RIS with THz and radio frequency (RF) links, aiming to combine the high-capacity advantage of THz with the reliability of RF. To this end, a dynamic threshold switching (DTS) scheme is introduced, enabling real-time selection between THz and RF links based on the instantaneous signal-to-noise ratio. A complete analytical framework is developed, incorporating hardware impairments, pointing errors, and generalized <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\alpha -\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula> fading in both RF and THz domains. The model incorporates deterministic RIS gains and frequency-dependent THz absorption, offering practical insights into the joint impact of RIS geometry, beam width, and switching thresholds. Closed-form expressions for outage probability, symbol error rate, ergodic capacity, and energy efficiency are derived. Simulation results confirm the accuracy of the proposed model and demonstrate that the hybrid system outperforms single-band THz or RF links and traditional diversity combining schemes. Additionally, increasing RIS elements improves performance and reduces transmit power requirements, with energy efficiency trends identifying optimal RIS configurations for practical deployment. These findings establish RIS-assisted hybrid THz/RF systems as a key enabler of reliable, high-capacity 6G communication for autonomous vehicles and smart factories.

title: AI-powered Chatbot for Retail E-commerce using Machine Learning & Natural Language Processing
authors: Karthik Govardhanan
publish: 2025 9th SLAAI International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (SLAAI-ICAI)
abstract: This article presents a modular AI-driven retail ecommerce chatbot designed to elevate user engagement through advanced natural language understanding (NLU), dynamic dialogue management, and personalized product recommendations. The framework integrates hybrid natural language generation with a context-aware collaborative filtering recommendation engine, supported by fine-tuned transformer models for intent recognition and entity extraction. This combination enables the chatbot to deliver highly relevant, individualized suggestions while maintaining conversational fluidity. In contrast to traditional rule-based or classic machine learning baselines, the proposed system demonstrates measurable improvements in both accuracy and user experience. The adoption of distributed caching mechanisms ensures low-latency responses, allowing the chatbot to scale effectively in high-traffic retail environments. Empirical evaluations show significant gains in query classification accuracy, entity F 1 score, recommendation relevance, and dialogue completion, with users reporting overall higher satisfaction in experiments conducted on the MultiWOZ 2.1 retail subset. Beyond technical performance, the system showcases how intelligent dialogue agents can drive business value by improving product discovery, increasing conversion rates, and fostering stronger customer engagement. Future research should focus on dynamic knowledge integration, improved handling of context-switching, and continual learning to enhance adaptability in evolving retail scenarios. Additionally, challenges such as managing out-of-vocabulary entities, abrupt context shifts, and domain transfer remain critical areas to address for broader deployment.
