title: Intelligent Invoice Recognition Framework and Intelligent Accounting System Based on Improved Yolov4 Algorithm
authors: Wei Yang, Jiasheng Zhang
publish: 2025 20th International Joint Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Natural Language Processing (iSAI-NLP)
abstract: In response to the problems faced by small and medium-sized enterprises in invoice processing and accounting, such as low recognition accuracy, insufficient process automation, and difficulty in adapting hardware resources, this article constructs an intelligent invoice recognition framework and intelligent accounting system based on improved Yolov4 to achieve integrated intelligent operation of invoice processing and accounting business. The intelligent invoice recognition framework optimizes input quality through image preprocessing modules (tilt correction, contrast enhancement, noise removal), embeds LEF low-frequency enhancement module on the basis of Yolov4 to enhance the global structural information of invoices, combines CBAM attention mechanism to focus on key field areas, uses ECioU loss function to improve the accuracy of bounding box localization, and simplifies the backbone network to achieve lightweight design and adapt to ordinary hardware environments of small and medium-sized enterprises. The intelligent accounting system automates the entire process of invoice recognition, verification, duplicate checking, and accounting entry by integrating with tax inspection interfaces, building a unique database index, and pre-set accounting entry templates. The experimental results showed that the accuracy of invoice field extraction improved by Yolov4 reached 96.8%, mAP@0.5 96.5%; The intelligent accounting system reduces the processing time of a single invoice by 94.8% compared to manual methods, and achieves a 100% verification and duplicate reimbursement interception rate. This study effectively addresses the pain points in financial processing for small and medium-sized enterprises, providing technical support for their financial digital transformation.

title: Testing-Based Formal Verification for Software Dependability
authors: Shaoying Liu
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Dependable Systems and Their Applications (DSA)
abstract: Software dependability encompasses five critical properties: reliability, safety, integrity, availability, and maintainability. Ensuring these attributes throughout the software engineering process remains a significant and ongoing challenge. In this talk, I will begin by briefly outlining a general framework for developing dependable software. I will then focus on an advanced technique known as Testing-Based Formal Verification (TBFV), which integrates specification-based testing with formal methods to verify program correctness. TBFV is characterized by its ability to automatically verify the correctness of all program paths explored during testing, while also having the potential to uncover previously untested paths. This dual capability supports both validation and verification, enhancing the overall assurance of software quality. I will explain the core principles of TBFV, specific techniques it employs for fault prevention, validation, and verification, as well as the key challenges associated with its practical implementation. When fully realized, TBFV is expected to significantly reduce testing time and cost, and substantially improve software dependability.

title: Anti-Jamming Communication Framework for UAV based Defense Operations to Control AI-enabled Attacks
authors: Runhui Zhao, Hong Wen, Wenjing Hou, Li Jiang, Zhiwei Chen, Tao Tang, Xuewei Feng
abstract: Nowadays, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have become essential assets for defense operations, providing efficient and precise communication and surveillance capabilities in complex and hostile environments. Artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled jamming poses a critical threat to the security and reliability of UAV communication networks. To address this, we propose an offline-learning anti-jamming framework that leverages advanced algorithms, including deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and decision transformers (DT), to enhance UAV performance in intelligent jamming environments. This work adopts an offline, cloud-based training paradigm for anti-jamming, which learns from historical decision trajectories to handle uncertain and unseen jamming patterns and enable reliable decision making. The proposed framework constrains cumulative reward loss within a predefined bound while improving training stability and reducing the time complexity of DRL-based decision model training. The proposed framework exhibits greater performance of UAVs in controlling AI-enabled jams by showing remarkable results for the performance metrics such as Bit Error Rate (BER), Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR), Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR), Jamming Detection Time (JDT), and latency (delay in response). The extensive experimental outcomes illustrate the efficiency of the proposed framework in complex defense operations and uncertain environments for mitigating AI-enabled attacks by counteracting the jamming attempts.

title: Differentially-Private Multi-Tier Federated Learning: A Formal Analysis and Evaluation
authors: Frank Po-Chen Lin, Evan Chen, Dong-Jun Han, Christopher G. Brinton
abstract: While federated learning (FL) eliminates the transmission of raw data over a network, it is still vulnerable to privacy breaches from the communicated model parameters. Differential privacy (DP) is often employed to address such issues. However, the impact of DP on FL in multi-tier networks – where hierarchical aggregations couple noise injection decisions at different tiers, and trust models are heterogeneous across subnetworks–is not well understood. To fill this gap, we develop Multi-Tier Federated Learning with Multi-Tier Differential Privacy (<monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M2FDP</monospace>), a DP-enhanced FL methodology for jointly optimizing privacy and performance over such networks. One of the key principles of <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M2FDP</monospace> is to adapt DP noise injection across the established edge/fog computing hierarchy (e.g., edge devices, intermediate nodes, and other tiers up to cloud servers) according to the trust models in different subnetworks. We conduct a comprehensive analysis of the convergence behavior of <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M2FDP</monospace> under non-convex problem settings, revealing conditions on parameter tuning under which the training process converges sublinearly to a finite stationarity gap that depends on the network hierarchy, trust model, and target privacy level. We show how these relationships can be employed to develop an adaptive control algorithm for <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M2FDP</monospace> that tunes properties of local model training to minimize energy, latency, and the stationarity gap while meeting desired convergence and privacy criterion. Subsequent numerical evaluations demonstrate that <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M2FDP</monospace> obtains substantial improvements in these metrics over baselines for different privacy budgets and system configurations.

title: FreDA: Frequency-guided Degradation Adaptation Detail Injection Network for Pansharpening
authors: Zhiyuan Zhang, Haoxuan Li, Yini Peng, Xin Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Pansharpening fuses panchromatic (PAN) images with low-resolution multispectral (LRMS) images to generate high-resolution multispectral (HRMS) images with rich spatial and spectral information, which can be widely used in change detection and other downstream tasks. However, existing pansharpening networks often use fixed spatial degradation to construct training data. Moreover, conventional fusion paradigms in both spatial and frequency domains generally rely on predetermined strategies, which fail to dynamically adapt to the distinctive characteristics of individual images. To solve the above problems, we proposed a frequency-guided detail injection pansharpening network (FreDA), which consists of a spectral restriction sub-network (SimNet) and an image fusion sub-network (FNet). The SimNet uses the learnable convolution layer to characterize the degradation parameters, which is used to construct spectral restriction loss. The FNet is constructed with the proposed frequency-guided detail injection (FGI) module, which is designed based on the relationship between frequency information and image degradation condition. The proposed FreDA framework introduces a degradation-aware synchronization mechanism that dynamically aligns spatial degradation patterns with adaptive detail injection weights, achieving significant quality enhancement in multi-satellite data. Extensive experiments on both simulated and full-resolution datasets demonstrate its superiority over state-of-the-art methods. Furthermore, rigorous module-level ablation studies validate the indispensability of each component.

title: Millimeter-sized 0.1pM-LoD Wireless 16-Channel Organic Electrochemical Transistors Based Electrochemical Sensing SoC
authors: Yuan Ma, Shangbin Liu, Lingfeng Wu, Yahao Song, Chao Xie, Lan Yin, Milin Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Circuits and Systems
abstract: This paper proposes a millimeter-sized, high-sensitivity, wide dynamic-range 16-channel electrochemical sensing SoC with integrated thin-film organic electrochemical transistor (OECT), utilizing ultrasonic wireless power and backscatter wireless communication technology. A bidirectional current conveyor and resistor (CC+R) potentiostat with duty-cycle control is introduced to minimize the static current consumption by reducing the duty cycle of the OECT amplification process. Additionally, the programmable gain amplifier’s (PGA’s) sampling capacitor is repurposed for small current-to-voltage conversion, extending the measurement range with minimal overhead. The system further integrates an active full-wave rectifier with backscatter amplitude modulation, supporting a wide range of received pulse amplitudes, variable time-of-flight (ToF), and tunable ultrasound frequencies. The design is fabricated using a 180 nm CMOS process. Experimental result features a sensing current measurement range of 184 dB, with a minimum current noise of 1.25 pArms. The power consumption of the single-channel system is 16.3 $μ$W. The design was validated for the detection of inflammatory factors, achieving a limit of detection (LoD) as low as 0.1 pM and the linearity with R2 greater than 0.95.

title: HIER: Heterogeneous Information Bottleneck and Expert Routing for Social Bot Detection
authors: Kun Lu, Hongli Zhang, Yuchen Yang, Chao Meng, Binxing Fang
abstract: Social bots constitute a substantial fraction of active accounts on digital platforms, fundamentally threatening information authenticity and democratic discourse. Contemporary detection methods confront critical limitations: information imbalance across heterogeneous relations, computational challenges in processing massive neighborhoods, and inadequate multi-scale representation learning. We propose HIER (Heterogeneous Information Bottleneck and Expert Routing), a pioneering framework that integrates variational information theory with mixture-of-experts paradigms for social network analysis. HIER introduces relation-aware variational information bottleneck for optimal compression across relationship types, dynamic sparse expert routing that extends mixture-of-experts to edge-level graph processing, and dual-scale mutual information maximization enhancing representation discriminability through neighborhood consistency and graph-level contrastive learning. Experimental validation demonstrates HIER's superior performance across real-world datasets, establishing new benchmarks for heterogeneous social bot detection.

title: Markov Potential Game Construction and Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning with Applications to Autonomous Driving
authors: Huiwen Yan, Mushuang Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: Markov games (MGs) provide a mathematical foundation for multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL), enabling self-interested agents to learn their optimal policies while interacting with others in a shared environment. However, due to the complexities of an MG problem, seeking (Markov perfect) Nash equilibrium (NE) is often very challenging for a general-sum MG. Markov potential games (MPGs), which are a special class of MGs, have appealing properties such as guaranteed existence of pure NEs and guaranteed convergence of gradient play algorithms, thereby leading to desirable properties for many MARL algorithms in their NE-seeking processes. However, the question of how to construct MPGs has been open. This paper provides sufficient conditions on the reward design and on the Markov decision process (MDP), under which an MG is an MPG. Numerical results on autonomous driving applications are reported.

title: Mitigating Hysteresis in Metal-Coated Fibers via Optimized Thermal Treatment for Advanced Distributed High-Temperature Sensing Applications
authors: Koustav Dey, Rony Kumer Saha, Bohong Zhang, S. Narasimman, Farhan Mumtaz, Jeffrey D. Smith, Rex E. Gerald, Ronald J. O’Malley, Jie Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Metal-coated optical fibers are widely employed in sensing applications owing to their superior mechanical strength and corrosion resistance. However, their calibration at elevated temperatures is hindered by hysteresis, manifested as discrepancies between heating and cooling cycles, primarily caused by residual strain from mismatched thermal expansion coefficients (TECs) between the metal coating and silica cladding. This research introduces an optimal heat treatment procedure aimed at minimizing the impact of the mismatch in TECs between the cladding and the coating materials that causes the residual strain in gold (Au) and copper (Cu) coated fibers for achieving reliable distributed high temperature sensing up to 500 °C using Optical Frequency Domain Reflectometry (OFDR) technology. The treatment facilitates stress relaxation and microstructural modifications, including surface diffusion, grain growth and oxidation (for Cu coatings), which collectively induce partial interfacial delamination and thereby suppress hysteresis. This work presents the first comprehensive experimental study to systematically investigate and demonstrate the mitigation of hysteresis through an optimized heat treatment process and its underlying mechanisms in metal-coated fibers, supported by microstructural insights. The identified treatment range of 25–300 °C achieves substantial reductions in residual strain, lowering hysteresis effects by approximately 90.2% in Cu-coated fibers and 86.6% in Au-coated fibers. Furthermore, Au-coated fibers exhibit a consistently lower degree of hysteresis than Cu-coated fibers under comparable thermal conditions. Heat treatment also enhances temperature sensitivity, with improvements of approximately 28.9% for Cu-coated fibers and 6.6% for Au-coated fibers. Post-treatment strain analysis confirms maximum sustainable strain limits of ~6000 με for Au-coated fibers and ~12,000 με for Cu-coated fibers. Both fiber types also demonstrated excellent thermal stability, maintaining consistent performance across three heating cycles between 25 °C and 300 °C over a 20-hour period. Collectively, the findings not only advance the scientific understanding of residual strain relaxation mechanisms but also provide a practical route toward robust, precise, and reliable distributed sensing for demanding industrial environments such as the steel, oil and gas sectors.

title: Non-Invasive Temperature Monitoring Hyperthermia with Size-Adjustable Ring Array
authors: Yuchen Sun, Ze Li, Lei Li, Jie Yuan, Nishan Dong, Junjie Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Hyperthermia therapy is a promising treatment approach for different tumors (e.g., extremity tumors, breast tumors), yet current systems lack a reliable non-invasive temperature monitoring method, hindering widespread clinical adoption. There is a definite relationship between the speed of sound (SOS) and the temperature of human tissues, which makes SOS imaging a suitable approach for non-invasive temperature monitoring in hyperthermia. We developed a preclinical system prototype for the SOS-based temperature monitoring method. The core device of the system is a size-adjustable ring array ultrasound transducer that integrates three critical functionalities: tumor localization via ultrasound reflection imaging, focused ultrasound heating with electronic focusing, and SOS-based temperature monitoring. By integrating imaging, heating, and temperature monitoring into a single acoustic platform, the system reduces alignment errors associated with multi-device systems and improves clinical efficiency. The ring array can be quickly adapted to different hyperthermia targets (radius from 65 mm to 105 mm) with a non-iterative calibration algorithm, enhancing clinical practicality. Ex vivo experiments demonstrate that the system enables reliable temperature monitoring while performing hyperthermia. Our all-acoustic hyperthermia system might address key challenges in temperature monitoring reliability, hyperthermia adaptability, and clinical workflow integration. This study validates a prototype system that successfully integrates SOS-based temperature monitoring with focused ultrasound heating via a size-adjustable ring array. The study establishes a basis for further technological refinement and may inform future research aimed at eventual clinical translation.

title: Integrating Aerial and Ground Users: Deep Reinforcement Learning and Convex Optimization for Data Power Control in Cell-Free Networks
authors: Juno V. Saraiva, Roberto P. Antonioli, Gábor Fodor, Walter C. Freitas, Yuri C. B. Silva
abstract: This paper addresses the power control problem in cell-free uplink networks, containing both aerial users and traditional terrestrial users in the same network. In particular, we study the data power control optimization problem to maximize the weighted sum of the spectral efficiencys (SEs), where each network user must satisfy its minimum SE demand. By adjusting the SE contribution weights for terrestrial and aerial users, we selectively prioritize certain user groups. Such model enhances current connectivity by addressing the needs and utilization behaviors of different user groups. In this context, we first introduce a centralized solution as the upper bound of solving the problem, which is mainly based on convex optimization. Then, we propose three decentralized solutions to solve the problem. The first solution focuses on coordinate descent techniques and still benefits from the support of convex optimization. Meanwhile, the other two proposed solutions utilize distributed deep reinforcement learning, harnessing advanced machine learning techniques to build adaptive, self-improving systems designed to improve autonomously within intricate environments. Moreover, in the context of our learning-based approaches, we outline practical signaling considerations for a decentralized model. In our model, each user acts as an independent agent and tries to find the best policy locally, while minimizing the need for information exchange. In our analysis, we explore the implications of weighing the performance of ground and aerial users in terms of SE. Finally, the numerical analysis reveals that the performance of our decentralized solutions closely matches that of the centralized and convex approach.

title: Full W-Band Broadband High-Gain Monopulse Gap Waveguide CTS Array Antenna with Hybrid Beamformer and Comparator Network
authors: Pengcheng Wang, Nannan Wang, Li Zhang, Yuzhong Wang, Qiming Wang, Yayun Cheng, Jiaran Qi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a broadband high-gain monopulse continuous transverse stub (CTS) array antenna based on gap waveguide technology, with its operating bandwidth covering the full W-band. The antenna comprises a novel hybrid beamformer and monopulse comparator network and a 16-element corporate-fed CTS array. A broadband sum and difference mode simultaneous excitation approach within the parallel-plate waveguide is explored, using a dual-mode planar horn with orthogonal port excitation. This approach is further implemented in dual reverse pillbox systems, combined with a magic-T and an E-plane divider, to realize a low-complexity monopulse array feed network with minimal components, thereby enabling broadband operation and high efficiency for the entire antenna. A prototype of the antenna has been fabricated and tested, with the measured results showing excellent agreement with simulations. The antenna operates over a bandwidth of 75-110 GHz (37.8%), with reflection coefficients of all three ports below -10 dB and isolation better than 30 dB. The measured gain of the sum beam ranges from 30.1 to 33 dBi, with an average total efficiencies of 63.4% across the entire operating band. Moreover, for the difference beam, the measured null depth is less than -35dB, and the amplitude imbalance is better than 0.2 dB. The proposed antenna combines broad bandwidth, high gain, and high efficiency with ease of fabrication and assembly, making it suitable for mm-wave and sub-THz tracking applications.

title: Space-Time Array Radar Based on Direction Modulation: Concept and Analysis
authors: RUJIANG GUO, JIANMING WANG, GUANGXIN WU
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Direction modulation is a modulation technique where the beam direction changes with the transmission time, providing beam scanning within the pulse transmission time for array antennas. For array radars, intra-pulse beam scanning is a degree of freedom that has not been fully utilized but can be exploited. Based on this degree of freedom, this paper proposes the concept of space-time array (STA) radar, which refers to a radar where the transmit beam in the spatial dimension varies flexibly in the temporal dimension (including intra-pulse and inter-pulse). The STA radar achieves coverage of the region of interest through intra-pulse beam scanning during transmission and covers the same region through multi-beam reception. Both transmission and reception use high-gain beams, sharing a single array antenna through the T/R components. A significant advantage of STA radar is that it enables array radars to perform multiple radar functions simultaneously, without being constrained by the limitation of traditional phased array radars that require multiple functions to be executed sequentially in time. This paper presents the concept, principles, simulations, and potential advantages of STA radar. STA radar represents an approach to achieving important radar capabilities that are not easily achievable with current array radar architectures.

title: Satellite Remote Sensing Mission Scheduling for Ecological Monitoring: A Learning-Based Multi-Region Collaborative Approach
authors: Senbao Wang, Di Zhou, Min Sheng, Wenwei Yue, Wenjie Zhang, Bakhtiyor Pulatov
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Utilizing remote sensing satellites for ecological area observation to provide timely high-resolution imagery is crucial for detailed ecological analysis. However, the extensive coverage of ecological areas and the limitation that a single satellite can only cover a limited target area at any given time lead to complex scheduling conflicts of imaging resources, thereby reducing observation coverage and mission completion rates. To address these challenges, this paper firstly proposes an multi-satellite cooperative regional target mission scheduling framework that integrates satellites, target areas and ground stations. Specifically, the target areas are segmented into grid spaces, upon which an adaptive scanning area calculation model driven by satellite attitude is developed. Additionally, a strip segmentation method tailored for regional targets is designed to maximize observation efficiency while minimizing resource wastage. The communication constraints between the satellite and the ground station are also fully considered in the framework to ensure that the acquired observation data can be efficiently and reliably transmitted to the ground station. Furthermore, this paper introduces a Multi-Agent Deep Policy Gradient Satellite Regional Mission Scheduling (MSRTS) algorithm that promotes collaboration through a shared resource pool among all agents. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed MSRTS algorithm significantly enhances the mission completion rate, with an average increase in benefits of approximately 9.72%. These f indings provide robust technical support for future large-scale real-time ecological remote sensing monitoring across multiple regions.

title: A Multi-Surface Low-SAR MIMO Antenna for Mobile Phone Based on Collinear Reverse Currents and Multiple Hotspots
authors: Quan Deng, Qing-Xin Chu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A multi-surfaces low-specific absorption rate (SAR) multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) antenna for mobile phone is proposed based on collinear reverse currents and multiple hotspots, and implemented by reactance loading. The proposed antenna element mainly consists of a common-mode (CM) dipole, a T-shaped power divider, and a center-loaded inductor. The T-shaped power divider is used to generate multiple peak points of tangential electric field and SAR by exciting the dual-end-fed CM dipole with collinear reverse current. The center-loaded inductor, analyzed by an equivalent circuit, further modifies the current distribution to uniform energy distribution, resulting in a multi-surface low-SAR antenna. Furthermore, by analyzing the position and the phase of the four antennas, the multi-surface low-SAR MIMO antenna is obtained. The fabricated antenna element and MIMO antenna can cover the -6dB bandwidth of 3.4 GHz-3.6 GHz, with the isolation of better than 17.5dB, envelope correlation coefficients (ECCs) of lower than 0.065 and efficiencies ranges from 85% to 95% and from 79.1% to 85.1%, respectively. The normalized measured SARs for the antenna element and MIMO antenna are 0.82 W/kg and 0.42 W/kg, respectively, which not only comply with the standards, but also ensure that SARs of the proposed antenna across multiple surfaces remain consistently low.

title: Stochastic Analysis on the Factors Affecting Critical Current and Index Value of Multi-Tape Co-Wound NI HTS Coil
authors: Jung Tae Lee, Geonyoung Kim, Hyunsoo Park, Jeonghwan Park, Chaemin Im, Wonseok Jang, Jaemin Kim, Seungyong Hahn
abstract: The estimation of critical current (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I_{\rm{c}}$</tex-math></inline-formula>) and the index value for single-tape wound coils and magnets is relatively straightforward. However, for multi-tape co-wound coils, the process becomes complex due to various factors influencing current distribution within the coil. This study conducts a numerical analysis to explore these factors and their impact on the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I_{\rm{c}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> and index value of multi-tape co-wound HTS coils. An equivalent circuit model, the multi-tape turn distributed circuit, is utilized to represent each tape turn in the coil. Key parameters such as the 77K self-field <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I_{\rm{c}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> of REBCO (Rare Earth Barium Copper Oxide) tape, its index value, contact resistance, and lead resistance are treated as variables during the charging simulation. A stochastic approach is employed to analyze the relationship between these parameters and the coil's <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I_{\rm{c}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> and index value through multiple simulations using randomly generated parameter values. The results demonstrate a strong correlation between the coil <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I_{\rm{c}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> and the average <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I_{\rm{c}}$</tex-math></inline-formula> of the REBCO tapes. Furthermore, the coil index value is found to be significantly influenced by the average contact resistivity between the REBCO tapes, and both the coil parameters are irrelevant to the tape lead resistance.

title: Modular Smart Glasses for Real-Time Obstacle Detection in Blind Navigation
authors: Aida Araújo Ferreira, Carlos Alberto Leal de Barros, Thiago Ewerton B. Pereira, Maria Francielly A. de Santana, Isaque D. S. Silva, Felipe S. de Oliveira, Gilmar G. de Brito, Ioná M. B. R. Barbosa, Vânia Soares de Carvalho, Dalton Cézane Gomes Valadares, Ryan Vinicius Santos Morais, Ronaldo R. B. de Aquino
abstract: This paper describes an innovative assistive device that attaches to eyeglasses to aid the mobility of blind individuals. The device employs infrared or ultrasonic sensors to detect environmental obstacles, converting this information into tactile and auditory feedback, providing users with a broader and more accurate spatial awareness. The collected data is processed and translated into tactile signals (vibration) or auditory signals (via sound transducers). The interval of these signals varies based on the distance from obstacles, enabling users to make quick and safe decisions in real time (empirical tests indicated an average detection accuracy above 92% and a latency of approximately 120–150 ms between detection and feedback). Currently, the most common mobility aids for visually impaired individuals are white canes and guide dogs, which have significant limitations. Canes are restricted to detecting obstacles from waist level downward and have a short range, while guide dogs are expensive and require extensive training. Hence, developing a portable and discreet technology capable of detecting obstacles beyond the reach of traditional canes is essential to improve the independence and safety of these individuals. The device was designed to be lightweight, comfortable, and aesthetically discreet, without compromising the user’s autonomy or quality of life. Financial accessibility is also prioritized, with efforts to utilize low-cost materials and technologies to enable large-scale production, benefiting as many individuals as possible. By addressing a recurrent challenge with a practical solution, this project offers a novel approach to mobility, autonomy, and inclusion for visually impaired individuals, expanding their ability to interact with their surroundings.

title: WeatherCycle: Unpaired Multi-Weather Restoration via Color Space Decoupled Cycle Learning
authors: Wenxuan Fang, Jiangwei Weng, Jianjun Qian, Jian Yang, Jun Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Unsupervised image restoration under multi-weather conditions remains a fundamental yet underexplored challenge. While existing methods often rely on task-specific physical priors, their narrow focus limits scalability and generalization to diverse real-world weather scenarios. In this work, we propose WeatherCycle, a unified unpaired framework that reformulates weather restoration as a bidirectional degradation-content translation cycle, guided by degradation-aware curriculum regularization. At its core, WeatherCycle employs a lumina-chroma decomposition strategy to decouple degradation from content without modeling complex weather, enabling domain conversion between degraded and clean images. To model diverse and complex degradations, we propose a Lumina Degradation Guidance Module (LDGM), which learns luminance degradation priors from a degraded image pool and injects them into clean images via frequency-domain amplitude modulation, enabling controllable and realistic degradation modeling. Additionally, we incorporate a Difficulty-Aware Contrastive Regularization (DACR) module that identifies hard samples via a CLIP-based classifier and enforces contrastive alignment between hard samples and restored features to enhance semantic consistency and robustness. Extensive experiments across serve multi-weather datasets, demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance among unsupervised approaches, with strong generalization to complex weather degradations.

title: Development of Stacks-in-Conduit Conductor (SICC) for High-Field HTS Magnets
authors: Sanghyeun Je, Youngkyoung Kim, Iksang Shin, Sangjun Oh, Geonwoo Baek, Wonwoo Park, Heekyung Choi, Kyuhan Choi
abstract: To enable high-current, internally-cooled high temperature superconductors (HTS) for fusion magnets, we developed a Stacks-in-Conduit Conductor (SICC) manufacturing process and produced prototype conductors. The SICC consists of a densely stacked REBCO tape bundle enclosed in a metal conduit (jacket) with an internal coolant channel, combining the high current density of stacked HTS tapes with the robust mechanical support and cooling of a cable-in-conduit design. A four-step continuous fabrication line was established, including automated tape stacking, bundle restacking, helical reinforcement insertion, and multi-stage roll forming into a square cross-section. Using aluminum dummy bundles and stainless steel (STS) tape stacks, we carried out forming trials to analyze mechanical and geometrical characteristics. An initial single-helix internal support led to a “wiggling” surface defect on the jacket, but this was resolved by adopting a double-helix (two counter-wound copper spirals) that cancels asymmetric forces, yielding a smooth outer surface. Micro-focus X-ray CT imaging confirmed that the HTS tape bundle remains intact after forming. These results demonstrate a viable manufacturing route for HTS SICC, and provide key insights on mechanical reinforcement and process optimization. The developed techniques lay a foundation for future SICC prototypes using actual HTS tapes, moving toward high-field fusion magnet applications.

title: DGNSCA: A Domain Generalized Network Leveraging Similarity and Class-Conditional Contrast for Robust Fault Diagnosis of Rotating Machinery under Unseen Operating Conditions
authors: Chaochao Guo, Youchao Sun
abstract: Timely and accurate detection of bearing faults is critical to the reliability of rotating machinery, yet models trained under fixed conditions often fail on unseen domains owing to distribution shifts. To overcome this limitation, we develop DGNSCA—a Domain Generalization Network that leverages Similarity guidance, Class-conditional feature alignment, and Adversarial training to learn domain-agnostic yet class-discriminative features. The architecture is built on a 1D convolutional neural network and incorporates three key modules: global distribution alignment to extract domain-invariant features, class-conditional contrastive learning to enhance intra-class consistency across domains, and adversarial training to improve generalization. DGNSCA further introduces a domain-similarity-guided decision module that adaptively aggregates per-source predictions via similarity weights, enabling robust inference without access to target-domain data. Comprehensive evaluations on two widely recognized benchmark datasets show that DGNSCA consistently surpasses current leading methods regarding accuracy, precision, and F1-score. Ablation analyses further validate the distinct contribution of each module within the framework. These results indicate that DGNSCA provides a reliable and scalable solution for intelligent fault diagnosis under realistic, distribution-shifted operating conditions.

title: Validation of Enhancement of Information Technology Hardware Support Model Service Towards the Service Quality
authors: Azham Ahmad, Adzhar Kamaludin
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Software Engineering &amp; Computer Systems (ICSECS)
abstract: Information technology hardware is the fastestevolving technology, which requires timely and strong support services to get them up and running seamlessly. This paper discusses the validation model output that runs based on the actual data using the Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modelling software. The model itself is derived from the information system theories. The validation from the model itself proves that the output from each construct is well balanced and can be used for future research, especially in the IT service support area. For this purpose, the items from the Service Quality (SERVQUAL) and IT Service Expertise were evaluated using questionnaires. As for the example of practical, the data derived from an actual study which was conducted on 305 users from different companies and organizations, including educational services, was applied. The questionnaire consists of 18 questions with 5 scales of Likert points that were used to identify the item data consistency. The association between observed parameters or indicators and their corresponding latent constructs or factors is represented by outer loadings in Partial Least Squares Structural Equation (PLS-SEM). The indicators are related to the fundamental construct that they are intended to measure; these values are essential. Based on the sufficient strength, the measured outer loading values, which range from 0.649 to 0.892, show high reliability through representing latent structures, as indicated by values near 0.90, while values above 0.60 are typically regarded as acceptable. Strong item-to-construct relationships are reflected in this model range.

title: Research on Industrial Robot Fault Diagnosis Based on Deep Learning
authors: Xinyang Wang, Liu Yu, Wenyao Zong
publish: 2025 20th International Joint Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Natural Language Processing (iSAI-NLP)
abstract: This study proposes an end-to-end deep learning diagnostic framework called “FCN-NLB+DBN+DSmT” to address the challenges of strong non-stationary vibration signals and multiple concurrent fault diagnosis in the operation of mechanical industrial robots. By collecting joint and end effector vibration signals through an accelerometer array, adaptive noise suppression is achieved by embedding non local blocks (FCN-NLB) into a fully convolutional neural network. Combined with multi-layer unsupervised feature learning of deep belief networks (DBN) and multi-source evidence fusion of Dezert Smarandache theory (DSmT), a three-level diagnostic system of “noise reduction feature extraction decision optimization” is constructed. The experiment shows that the framework improves the signal-to-noise ratio to 11.3 dB in a -10 dB noise environment, and the diagnostic accuracy of four joint concurrent faults reaches 94.3%, which is 9.3% higher than a single DBN model. The study has verified the effectiveness of deep learning and multi-source information fusion in complex industrial scenarios, providing a robust and generalized solution for robot fault diagnosis. In the future, we will focus on model lightweight design and multimodal data fusion to promote practical applications in industrial fields.

title: Light-Weight Hierarchical Attention-Compression Based DiseaseClassification from X-Ray Images
authors: Muneesh, Ruchi Sehrawat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Innovations for Sustainable Solutions (ICDISS)
abstract: Clinical radiography, especially in resource-constrained settings, needs automated X-ray disease classification, to improve diagnosis accuracy and save burden. Existing methods have trouble combining information from different scales and lowering their complexity. This makes it hard to capture complex spatial and channel-wise correlations while keeping computing speed. To overcome these limitations, a novel and extremely light-weight HACNet model with just 1.43 million parameters, has been proposed. It contains a novel Hierarchical Attention-Compression Module (HACM) to boost feature representational capacity. A Feature Aggregation Unit (FAU) uses dense connectivity and a Triplet Attention layer to fuse multi-scale feature maps, and the Attentional Compression Unit (ACU) reduces dimensionality using strided convolution and channel and spatial attention mechanisms. Experimental results on the Covid19 radiography dataset and the ChestX-ray8 dataset demonstrate strong classification capabilities of the proposed model in identifying diseases from x-ray images. The proposed model is computationally efficient than popular computer vision models and demonstrates excellent qualitative capabilities as demonstrated from t-SNE plots.

title: Finding Conditions for Target Controllability under Christmas Trees
authors: Marco Peruzzo, Giacomo Baggio, Francesco Ticozzi
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper presents new graph-theoretic conditions for structural target controllability of directed networks. After reviewing existing conditions and highlighting some gaps in the literature, we introduce a new class of network systems, named Christmas trees, which generalizes trees and cacti. We then establish a graph-theoretic characterization of sets of nodes that are structurally target controllable for a simple subclass of Christmas trees. Our characterization applies to general network systems by considering spanning subgraphs of Christmas tree class and allows us to uncover target controllable sets that existing criteria fail to identify.

title: Efficient Chest X-Ray Classification via Knowledge Distillation: Realizing Edge-Ready Deep Models
authors: Sarah Rashidi, Hussein Hazimeh, Hassan Harb
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Emerging Trends in Engineering and Computing (ETECOM)
abstract: Deploying deep learning for chest X-ray interpretation in clinical settings faces persistent challenges, including heavy computational requirements, high latency, and limited hardware resources that restrict the use of state-of-the-art models. To address these constraints, knowledge distillation is leveraged to compress a high-capacity DenseNet121 into a streamlined ResNet18 while maintaining clinical performance. The approach is benchmarked using the NIH ChestX-ray14 dataset, targeting multi-label disease classification. Results show that the distilled student achieves a mean ROC-AUC of 0.81, exceeding the teacher’s 0.79, while reducing multiply-add operations by 36%, slashing inference latency by a factor of 4.6 (0.20 ms vs. 0.92 ms per image), and cutting peak GPU memory usage by 60% (85 MB vs. 209 MB). These outcomes confirm that efficient model compression through knowledge distillation enables rapid, reliable, and resource-friendly deployment of diagnostic AI in real-world medical environments.

title: Detection of Lead Contamination in Indus River using Computer Vision and Remote Sensing
authors: Usama Kundi, Rafia Mumtaz, Mehreen Ahmed, Sadaf Mumtaz, Muhammad Ajmal Khan, Muhammad Saqib Irshad
publish: 2025 IEEE 22nd International Conference on Smart Communities: Improving Quality of Life using AI, Robotics and IoT (HONET)
abstract: Water is the essence of life that is necessary for all living beings. Nonetheless, surface water contamination with lead (Pb) contributes to the onset of different ailments, and conventional approaches to identifying lead pollution are inefficient and time-consuming. Hence, this study presents remote sensing and computer vision methods for detecting lead contamination in several locations of the Indus River. The proposed technique utilizes multispectral satellite images to highlight the areas of water bodies polluted with lead. Moreover, machine learning and deep learning approaches, such as the Random Forest (RF), VGG16UNET model, and the Fully Convolutional Network(FCN), are used to detect lead contamination. The results show that the RF outperformed other algorithms and achieved 73% accuracy. The VGG16UNET model outperformed other deep models like DeepLabv3. The VGG16UNET achieved a mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) score of 0.70. However, FCN had the greatest mIoU, at 0.65, for the augmented solution. Thus, the proposed method has enhanced the monitoring of the aquatic bodies in real-time with maximum area coverage. Moreover, the efficiency and accuracy achieved with the proposed method can help the officials and management to identify areas with polluted water.

title: Distributed Combined Space Partitioning and Network Flow Optimization: an Optimal Transport Approach
authors: Théo Laurentin, Patrick Coirault, Emmanuel Moulay, Antoine Lesage-Landry, Jerome Le Ny
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper studies a combined space partitioning and network flow optimization problem, with applications to large-scale electric power, transportation, or communication systems. In dense wireless networks for instance, one may want to simultaneously optimize the assignment of many spatially distributed users to base stations and route the resulting communication traffic through the backbone network. We formulate the overall problem by coupling a semi-discrete optimal transport (SDOT) problem, capturing the space partitioning component, with a minimum-cost flow problem on a discrete network. This formulation jointly optimizes the assignment of a continuous demand distribution to certain endpoint network nodes and the routing of flows over the network to serve the demand, under capacity constraints. As for SDOT problems, we establish that the formulation of our problem admits a tight relaxation taking the form of an infinite-dimensional linear program, derive its finite-dimensional dual, and prove that strong duality holds. We leverage this theory to design a distributed dual (super)gradient ascent algorithm solving the problem, where nodes in the graph perform computations based solely on locally available information. Simulation results illustrate the algorithm’s performance and its applicability to an electric power distribution network reconfiguration problem.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning for Early Detection of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Related Respiratory Events from Lung Sound Recordings
authors: Isra’a Misto, Nassib Abdallah, Bassam Daya
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Emerging Trends in Engineering and Computing (ETECOM)
abstract: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is a respiratory disease that is one of the top causes of illness and death worldwide. Although it is incurable, detecting it at an early stage leads to better management. Doctors rely on respiratory sounds, particularly crackles and wheezes which are hard to detect even by experts to identify COPD. The most effective diagnostic tool currently is the spirometry, but it is not always available in primary care or resource limited settings. In this study, we used the ICBHI 2017 Respiratory Sound Database to evaluate two hybrid deep learning architectures for anomaly level classification under cycle based splits as a lightweight baseline, with attention mechanisms and patient-level splits left for future work. Data augmentation and class balancing were applied to improve recognition of underrepresented classes. After applying augmentation and class balancing, our CNN-BiGRU model achieved promising results, reaching 74% accuracy, 0.90 AUC, 78% specificity, and 69% sensitivity. The models were evaluated under a cycle-level split condition that reflects real-world scenarios where systems repeatedly process data from the same patients under chronic conditions such as COPD. This work is presented as a step towards COPD-targeted screening. A future step will be mapping from discovered anomalies to specific disease patterns, including COPD.

title: Unsupervised Learning Approach for Network Anomaly Detection with Thresholding Reconstruction Error Based on Deep Autoencoder
authors: Karin Hagaina Ginting, Parman Sukarno, Aulia Arif Wardana
publish: 2025 IEEE 9th International Conference on Software Engineering &amp; Computer Systems (ICSECS)
abstract: Traditional approaches to anomaly detection are often limited and less effective in dealing with new and unknown threats, including DDoS attacks. Distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks are a rapidly growing threat that disrupts systems and makes services unavailable. This research aims to detect unlabeled attacks and classify whether the data is anomalous or normal by using a deep autoencoder model. Deep autoencoder is a network designed to reconstruct input data with a high degree of accuracy. This research includes pre-processing, normalization, feature selection, and reconstruction error as a comparison to determine normal and anomalous data. Threshold selection with the best ROC to measure sensitivity and false alarm rate on the 2019 CIC-DDos dataset. Evaluation results demonstrate that the model achieves high performance with precision, recall, and F1-score all reaching 97 percent. These results compare favorably with previous studies with the same dataset in unsupervised learning. The method works well to detect new and unknown attacks to prevent the system from being tampered with and provide more robust attack detection.

title: Design, Modelling and Analysis of a Bio-inspired Spiking Temperature Regulator
authors: J.M. Rosito, E. Petri, E. Steur, W.P.M.H. Heemels
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: In biology, homeostasis is the process of maintaining a stable internal environment, which is crucial for optimal functioning of organisms. One of the key homeostatic mechanisms is thermoregulation that allows the organism to maintain its core temperature within tight bounds despite being exposed to a wide range of varying external temperatures. Instrumental in thermoregulation is the presence of thermosensitive neurons at multiple places throughout the body, including muscles, the spinal cord, and the brain, which provide spiking sensory signals for the core temperature. In response to these signals, thermoeffectors are activated, creating a negative spiking feedback loop. Additionally, a feedforward signal is provided by warmth and cold-sensitive neurons in the skin, offering a measure for the external temperature. This paper presents an electronic circuit-based architecture design to replicate the biological process of thermoregulation, combined with a formal mathematical analysis. The considered architecture consists of four temperature sensitive neurons and a single actuator, configured in a negative feedback loop with feedforward control. To model the overall system mathematically, hybrid dynamical system descriptions are proposed that are used to analyze and simulate the performance of the design. The analysis and numerical case study illustrate the crucial role of feedforward control in reducing the dependency on the external temperature.

title: A Distributed Measurement Method for TRP and TIS of Multi-Transceiver SISO Systems in Intelligent Connected Vehicles
authors: Guotian Ji, Penghui Shen, Miao Yi, Hao Jia, Gang Lv, Tianhao Wang
abstract: The comprehensive integration of wireless technology in intelligent connected vehicles (ICVs) demands rigorous and practical Over-the-air (OTA) performance testing. However, the large physical dimensions of vehicles render direct application of standardized mobile phone testing methods outlined by Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association and 3rd Generation Partnership Project impractical. Employing compact antenna test range for vehicle testing faces significant challenges such as high costs and potential safety hazards during 3D rotation for a vehicle, while existing spherical near-field testing methods fail to accurately evaluate the Total Radiated Power (TRP) and Total Isotropic Sensitivity (TIS) for multi-antenna spatial diversity systems, a common configuration in modern ICVs to ensure robust coverage. This paper proposes a novel, efficient, and comprehensive measurement methodology specifically designed for TRP and TIS testing of multiple transceivers, addressing the gap in current approaches. The solution involves characterizing the passive radiation patterns of the vehicle’s multiple antennas and functionally isolating individual transceivers to determine their respective port radiated power and radiated sensitivity. These parameters are then used to calculate the effective isotropic radiated power and effective isotropic sensitivity, ultimately deriving the overall multi-antenna TRP and TIS. In addition to precision, a significant advantage of this method is its dramatically reduced test time; for instance, TIS measurement for a single frequency band can be completed within thirty minutes instead of the dozens of hours required by traditional methods. This approach represents the only viable and practical solution for wireless performance evaluation of ICVs.

title: A distributed model predictive control architecture for mitigating cyber attack effects in multi-agent leader-follower formations
authors: Francesco Tedesco, Antonello Venturino, Domenico Famularo, Giuseppe Franzè
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper presents a resilient distributed receding horizon control framework for leader-follower multi-agent systems subject to false data injection attacks. The approach integrates a set-membership-based detection mechanism and predictive consistency checks to identify attacks in finite time. Two mitigation strategies are introduced: (i) altruistic recovery, where agents apply precomputed control actions during an attack, and (ii) adaptive formation reconfiguration, enabling dynamic leader switching and sub-formation rejoining to isolate compromised agents. The framework ensures constraint satisfaction, recursive feasibility, and closed-loop stability. Numerical simulations with unmanned aerial vehicles validate the method, demonstrating effective attack detection and recovery while maintaining formation integrity. Compared to existing approaches, this work uniquely combines model predictive control, anomaly detection, and topology adaptation for resilient multi-agent coordination.

title: A Dual-Band WBAN Antenna with Frequency Selective Surface (FSS) Reflector for Enhanced Gain in ISM Bands
authors: Youssef Frist, Chaïmaâ Kissi, Mourad Elhabchi, Mohamed Nabil Srifi
publish: 2025 7th International Symposium on Advanced Electrical and Communication Technologies (ISAECT)
abstract: This research suggests a new dual-band antenna for Wireless Body Area Networks (WBANs) applications that incorporates a Frequency Selective Surface (FSS). The use of the FSS is to improve the performance of the antenna by acting as a reflector and is based on a Split Ring Resonator (SRR) design. In a free-space environment, the integration reduced the reflection coefficient (S11) to -60 dB at 2.45 GHz (F1) and -40 dB at 5.8 GHz (F2). Additionally, the gain increased significantly, reaching 4.31 dBi and 4.64 dBi at F1 and F2, respectively. When evaluated on a human tissue (ht) model, the antenna's performance was shown to be stable and safe, with average SAR values of 1.1 W/Kg and 0.48 W/Kg for 1g and 10g, respectively, at both frequencies. It is a promising solution for high-performance wearable devices because these values are significantly lower than the IEEE 802.15.6 Standard. It is noteworthy that this initial work used a multi-layer model to simulate the human body for biomedical patient tracking applications. For every simulation, CST Microwave Studio was utilized. These results will be validated in subsequent work using a collection of voxel models and experimental observations.

title: A Pose Measurement Method for Vision Sensor in Slender Structures
authors: Xinyun Wang, Junhua Sun, Fuqiang Zhou, Jie Zhang
abstract: The 3D multi-view internal reconstruction of the slender pipeline is crucial for the internal surface inspection in industrial fields, where the pose of the reconstruction sensor directly affects the global stitching accuracy of the multiple views. However, conventional methods suffer from cumulative errors over a long distance. This paper proposes a pose measurement method via multi-sensor fusion for the vision reconstruction system in a slender structure. The process integrates a laser rangefinder for displacement measurement and an inclinometer for attitude determination, with spatial correlation achieved through a monocular camera tracking the laser spot projected onto a flat plate. Accordingly, we propose a combined calibration algorithm for the pose measurement system, using an auxiliary camera and a double-sided target. The experimental validation on a 200 mm wide and 6 m long platform shows that the proposed multi-sensor fusion method achieves an RMSE of 1.34 mm for 3D marker point reconstruction at a moving distance of 5 m.

title: MAFF-Net: A Deep Fusion Framework for Multimodal Recognition of LSS Targets
authors: Yanyu Wan, Junyan Chen, Lei Xiao, Biao Tian, Wenzhen Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: The accurate classification of Low, Slow, and Small (LSS) targets in low-altitude airspace is a critical challenge for surveillance and safety systems. While radar provides essential data, methods relying on a single information source, such as micro-Doppler signatures or kinematic tracks, are often unreliable due to low radar cross-sections and complex clutter environments. Consequently, multimodal fusion has emerged as a promising direction. However, the performance of conventional fusion algorithms is often compromised by their static fusion strategies, where fixed weights assigned during training cannot adapt to real-world scenarios in which the quality of a data stream may degrade. To address these limitations, this paper proposes the Multimodal Adaptive Feature Fusion Network (MAFF-Net), a multilevel dual-branch architecture designed to overcome the vulnerabilities of both single-source methods and static fusion. At each hierarchical level, a Semantic Bridge Module (SBM) first aligns heterogeneous features from different modalities using contrastive learning. Crucially, an Adaptive Fusion Module (AFM) then dynamically arbitrates the contribution of each information stream, enabling the network to intelligently rely on higher-quality data and mitigate the effects of signal distortion or loss. Evaluated on a comprehensive dataset collected from five distinct geographical sites, MAFF-Net achieves 91.01% accuracy, outperforming other advanced fusion methods by up to 2.0 percentage points. The model's robustness and practical utility are further validated through extensive cross-site testing and a successful in-the-field deployment.

title: Soft-switched Induction Cooking System with Reduced Switch Count and Independent Control for Multiple Loads
authors: Thoutreddy Deepthi Reddy, S Porpandiselvi
abstract: In this paper, a three-load resonant inverter (3LRI) with independent power control is proposed for induction cooking (IC) applications. Resonant inverter circuits are commonly employed in induction cookers due to their superior efficiency and capability for soft switching operation. Among the various topologies, the half-bridge series resonant inverter (HBSR) topology is used for its optimal balance between performance and cost. The major advantages of this inverter circuit with cyclic ON and OFFcontrol include simple, independent power control for every load, high efficiency for wide range of power variations, soft-switching and reduced number of switches per load. This configurationcan be easily extended for multiple loads by addition of another inverter legs. This configuration has been simulated using PSIM software. A 629 W experimental prototype is built to verify thetheoretical analysis. A peak efficiency of 96.1% is obtained. The experimental results confirm that this inverter configuration is a viable approach for multi-load induction cooking applications.

title:
Machine Learning Assisted Pb
                    <sup>2+</sup>
                    Ions Detection Using AlGaN/GaN HEMT Sensors
authors: Nidhi Mahesh Hegde, Pramod Martha, Adarsh Nigam
abstract: In this work, a novel machine learning-integrated AlGaN/GaN High Electron Mobility Transistor (HEMT) based sensor is reported for the detection of Pb<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2+</sup> ion contamination in aqueous media. Here, the gate region of the HEMT was functionalized with 2,5-dimercapto-1,3,4-thiadiazole (DMTD) to provide high affinity and selectivity toward Pb²⁺ ions. The DMTD functionalization enabled the device to exhibit excellent sensitivity at pH 5.5. Moreover, the lifetime stability analysis indicated consistent sensing performance over a period of 30 days. Furthermore, machine learning-based methodology was applied to detect the presence of Pb<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2+</sup> ions contamination in solution by analyzing the sensing response of AlGaN/GaN HEMT sensor. Here, a Random Forest classifier was trained on the obtained sensing response. The dataset was pre-processed, balanced using Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) to counteract class imbalance, and split into training (80%) and testing (20%) sets. The classifier achieved an accuracy of 90.50%, precision of 1.0 recall of 81.03%, and F1-score of 89.52%. Visualization through confusion matrix, Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curves, and learning curves also demonstrates the robustness and reliability of the proposed model. The integration of machine learning with DMTD functionalized AlGaN/GaN HEMT sensing platforms establishes a promising pathway for rapid, selective and stable Pb<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2+</sup> ion detection in water quality monitoring applications.

title: ConSignformer: Conformer-based Framework for Continuous Sign Language Recognition
authors: Neena Aloysius, Geetha M, Atul Sajjanhar, Prema Nedungadi
abstract: Continuous Sign Language Recognition (CSLR) is a challenging computer vision task that automatically recognizes sequences of sign language gestures from continuous video streams, aiming to bridge communication barriers for the deaf community. Conventional deep learning frameworks for CSLR consist of a single or multimodal feature extractor, a sequence-learning module and a decoder for outputting glosses. The sequence learning module is a crucial part wherein transformers have demonstrated their efficacy in the sequenceto- sequence tasks. However, experimentation in the sequencelearning component for sign language is limited. In this work, we present an innovative CSLR framework, ConSignformer, which combines the strengths of a hybrid network built with S3DCNN and a Conformer-based sequence-learning backbone. To enhance the sequence learning capabilities of the Conformer module, we propose a novel unsupervised pretraining strategy called Regressional Feature Extraction, which uniquely leverages sign pose videos as training data and employs Mean Squared Error loss. We then introduce Cross-Modal Relative Attention (CMRA), which further enhances the ability of the Conformer to learn and utilize complex relationships within the RGB and keypoints data. The experimental results confirm the effectiveness of the adopted pretraining strategy and demonstrate how CMRA contributes to the recognition process. Remarkably, by leveraging a Conformer-based backbone, our CSLR model achieves state-ofthe-art performance on the benchmark datasets: PHOENIX-2014 and PHOENIX-2014T.

title: Distributed Poisson multi-Bernoulli filtering via generalised covariance intersection
authors: Ángel F. García-Fernández, Giorgio Battistelli
abstract: This paper presents the distributed Poisson multi-Bernoulli (PMB) filter based on the generalised covariance intersection (GCI) fusion rule for distributed multi-object filtering. Since the exact GCI fusion of two PMB densities is intractable, we derive a principled approximation. Specifically, we approximate the power of a PMB density as an unnormalised PMB density, which corresponds to an upper bound of the PMB density. Then, the GCI fusion rule corresponds to the normalised product of two unnormalised PMB densities. We show that the result is a Poisson multi-Bernoulli mixture (PMBM), which can be expressed in closed form. Future prediction and update steps in each filter preserve the PMBM form, which can be projected back to a PMB density before the next fusion step. Experimental results show the benefits of this approach compared to other distributed multi-object filters.

title: Deep Learning-based Single-Snapshot DOA Estimation with a Unit-Nuclear-Norm Structured Covariance Prior
authors: Yujian Pan, Qidong Lin, Afeng Yang
abstract: Direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation from a single snapshot is more challenging than its multi-snapshot counterpart, yet it remains crucial for sensing applications. This paper proposes a deep learning-based method to reconstruct a Toeplitz and positive-definite array covariance matrix with the unit nuclear norm property. Rather than emphasizing the neural network architecture, our focus is placed on the design of the network output layer and the loss function. The output layer is designed to generate a learned spatial spectrum consisting of a fixed-size set of DOAs and their corresponding signal-to-noise ratios, based on which a Toeplitz and positive-definite covariance matrix is reconstructed. The unit nuclear norm constraint is hard-encoded into the covariance matrix without hyperparameters. The loss function is derived from a whitened fitting error, followed by a projected multiplicatively symmetric transformation. The Toeplitz and positive-definite structure fully captures the properties of a true covariance matrix, while the unit nuclear norm constraint promotes sparsity and eliminates the need to add an extra output head for noise variance estimation. The new loss function enhances the accuracy of estimating the smaller eigenvalues of the reconstructed matrix. Based on the reconstructed covariance matrix, the signal number and DOA estimation can be performed using conventional methods. Numerical simulations and outdoor measurements are utilized to demonstrate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method with the uniform linear array (ULA) and non-uniform linear array (NULA), as well as its robustness to array nonidealities.

title: A Compact High-Efficiency Ultra-wideband RF Rectifier for Electromagnetic Energy Harvesting
authors: Xingyu Huang, Wenbo Liu, Tao Wang, Yang Liu, Jishen Li, Sheng Wang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: This paper proposed a compact and highly effective ultra-wideband rectifier for energy harvesting applications in radio frequency (RF) ambient. To reduce the complexity of the matching network, the rectifier adopted a matching network without reactance branches(WRB) on the voltage doubling circuit. Two transmission lines with different matching functions are used to achieve broadband matching. The working band rectifier is significantly widened and the measurement results demonstrate that a rectification efficiency of more than 50% is maintained over a bandwidth of approximately 130% (0.45 to 2.15 GHz) at 8-dBm input power, with the maximum rectification efficiency of 75.4%.

title: A Tri-Band Shared-Aperture Base Station Antenna Array Covering 5G Mid-Band and 6G Centimetric Wave Band
authors: Shang-Yi Sun, Hai-Han Sun, Can Ding, Y. Jay Guo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This work proposes a tri-band shared-aperture antenna array with three wide bands, covering the 5G mid-band and the 6G centimetric band, which is a promising candidate for future 6G base station antennas. The challenge of suppressing interferences, including scattering and coupling, in the tri-band array is holistically addressed across wide bands. Guided by characteristic mode analysis (CMA), a segmented spiral radiator is efficiently developed to mitigate scattering and coupling at high frequencies while preserving radiation performance at low frequencies. Compared to a conventional tube radiator, the proposed spiral exhibits a reduced radar cross-section (RCS) over an ultra-wide range of 4.7-21.5 GHz (128.2%). With the aid of serial resonators, impedance matching of the segmented-spiral-based dipole antenna is achieved across the low band (LB) of 3.05-4.68 GHz (42.2%), spanning the 5G band 3.3-4.2 GHz. Moreover, suppressors are placed near the LB ports to further reduce the cross-band coupling. Middle band (MB) and high band (HB) antennas operate in 6.2-10.0 GHz (46.9%) and 10.0-15.6 GHz (43.8%), respectively, collectively covering the anticipated 5G-Advanced and 6G centimetric band of 6.425-15.35 GHz. Both the MB and HB antennas employ a planar magnetoelectric (ME) dipole structure, which prevents common-mode resonances in the LB and MB, and mitigates the scattering from the MB antenna in the HB. In this tri-band array, radiation patterns remain undistorted across the LB, MB, and HB, and the isolation between any two ports exceeds 20 dB over all three bands.

title: UAV-USV Collaborative Sensing System Based on Integrated Sensing and Communication
authors: Rui Zhang, Fuwang Dong, Wei Wang
abstract: To leverage the complementary advantages of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and unmanned surface vehicles (USVs) in coupled air-sea environments, we propose a cooperative sensing framework based on integrated sensing and communication (ISAC). The framework optimizes the UAV’s hover points, beamforming, and UAV & USV trajectories together to reduce overall system energy consumption. First of all, the hover point selection is formulated as a trade-off between the number of hover points and sensing distances. At each hover point, the UAV transmits ISAC signals for target sensing and maintains a communication link with the USV. Secondly, the system operates in two modes: flight mode and hover mode. In flight mode, the UAV and USV maintain stable communication while navigating safely to the hover points. In hover mode, the UAV remains stationary to perform S&C tasks, ensuring that each target meets the required cumulative sensing signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and that the communication rate with the USV is maintained. To solve the trajectory and beamforming optimization problem, we combine techniques such as Semidefinite Relaxation (SDR) and Successive Convex Approximation (SCA). Simulation results indicate that the proposed algorithm achieves notably lower energy consumption than the baseline scheme. They also reveal that the design of hover points achieves a balance between system energy consumption and the upper bound of sensing performance.

title: Statistical Analysis of end-to-end Route Feasibility in Converged Metro–Access Optical Networks
authors: Ahtisham Ali, Muhammad Umar Masood, Andrea Rosso, Gulmina Malik, Michela Pollone, Alessandro Galardini, Vittorio Curri
abstract: Disaggregation of the Radio Access Network (RAN) imposes stringent fronthaul latency and physical-layer performance requirements on supporting the optical transport infrastructure. This paper evaluates the feasibility of Access–DU–Access (A–DU–A) routes in a converged metro–access optical network, jointly considering Bit Error Rate (BER) and the fronthaul latency constraint of 250 μs, considering functional split 7.2 defined by 3GPP. Two deployment scenarios are examined: (i) DU/CU hosting at metropolitan Points of Presence (PoPs) and (ii) DU/CU hosting at external data centers (DCs). Using Cassini and Phoenix whiteboxes hosting pluggable DCO transceivers (TRxs), the analysis quantifies the impact of modulation format, BER thresholds, and end-to-end propagation latency on service feasibility. Results show that metro-based hosting supports 87.9% latency-compliant routes compared to 47.6% under data-center hosting, and that Cassini consistently provides higher BER feasibility across modulation formats. The findings demonstrate that physical-layer impairments and functional placement must be jointly optimized to support latency-constrained, virtualized RAN transport in converged metro–access networks.

title: Parallel Collaborative ADMM Privacy Computing and Adaptive GPU Acceleration for Distributed Edge Networks
authors: Mengchun Xia, Zhicheng Dong, Donghong Cai, Fang Fang, Lisheng Fan, Pingzhi Fan
abstract: Distributed computing has been widely applied in distributed edge networks for reducing the processing burden of high-dimensional data centralization, where a high-dimensional computational task is decomposed into multiple low-dimensional collaborative processing tasks or multiple edge nodes use distributed data to train a global model. However, the computing power of a single-edge node is limited, and collaborative computing will cause information leakage and excessive communication overhead. In this paper, we design a parallel collaborative distributed alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) and propose a three-phase parallel collaborative ADMM privacy computing (3P-ADMM-PC2) algorithm for distributed computing in edge networks, where the Paillier homomorphic encryption is utilized to protect data privacy during interactions. Especially, a quantization method is introduced, which maps the real numbers to a positive integer interval without affecting the homomorphic operations. To address the architectural mismatch between large- integer and Graphics Processing Unit (GPU) computing, we transform high-bitwidth computations into low-bitwidth matrix and vector operations. Thus the GPU can be utilized to implement parallel encryption and decryption computations with long keys. Finally, a GPU-accelerated 3P-ADMM-PC2 is proposed to optimize the collaborative computing tasks. Meanwhile, large-scale computational tasks are conducted in network topologies with varying numbers of edge nodes. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed 3P-ADMM-PC2 has excellent mean square error performance, which is close to that of distributed ADMM without privacy-preserving. Compared to centralized ADMM and distributed ADMM implemented with Central Processing Unit (CPU) computation, the proposed scheme demonstrates a significant speedup ratio.

title: Transforming Blood Infection Diagnostics: AI and Electronic Noses Target Candida
authors: Michael L. Bastos, Christina Cox, Clayton A. Benevides, Cícero P. Inácio, Rejane P. Neves, Frederico D. De Menezes, Margaret V. Powers-Fletcher, Leandro M. Almeida
abstract: Candidemia is a severe fungal bloodstream infection with high mortality rates, especially in immunocompromised patients. Traditional diagnostic methods, such as blood cultures, suffer from low sensitivity and long turnaround times, delaying targeted antifungal therapy. In this study, we explore the potential of electronic noses (e-noses) combined with artificial intelligence (AI) models to provide a rapid and accurate diagnosis of Candida infections directly from blood culture broth samples. Samples were analyzed using an e-nose, generating datasets that underwent preprocessing steps including outlier removal, cycle equalization, feature transformation, and optional oversampling to address species imbalances. To ensure clinical relevance, we employed a dual-scenario validation strategy, assessing both intra-sample sensor stability and inter-sample biological generalization. We tested both traditional machine learning models and time series classifiers, selecting models based on prior research and performance in similar tasks. The best-performing models were evaluated based on accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, specificity, and computational efficiency. Results demonstrated that while the framework achieved > 98% consistency in sensor stability tests, the Support Vector Classifier (SVC) emerged as the most robust model for generalization, achieving statistical parity with complex Time Series models like InceptionTime, but with significantly higher computational efficiency. This study highlights the feasibility of AI-enhanced e-noses for rapid Candida detection, offering a promising alternative to conventional diagnostics in clinical settings.

title: A Local Ray Incidence-Based Scattering Model for Targets on a Complex Rough Surface
authors: Zun Zhang, Kun-Yi Guo, Xin Yuan, Junjun Yin, Xin-Qing Sheng, Jian Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper proposes a novel high-frequency scattering model for targets on complex rough surfaces. The core innovation is a local ray incidence-based technique that computes the reflection and multi-reflection components from targets and the coupling scattering components between targets and the background. This approach generates ray tubes exclusively from the target facet model. The background facet model is subsequently processed to perform ray-triangle intersection tests, while coupling scattering components are modified using the four-path principle. Background scattering is calculated via coherent-incoherent models, and diffraction components are computed using the Equivalent Electromagnetic Current (EEC) method. The accuracy of the proposed method is validated against full-wave numerical solvers, showing good agreement in radar cross-section (RCS) fluctuations. Compared to the traditional Shooting and Bouncing Rays (SBR) technique with EEC, the proposed method achieves a significant reduction in simulation time. This capability enables the rapid simulation of SAR images for targets on complex rough surfaces.

title: Intelligent Weed Detection: A Comparative Study of Machine Learning and Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Abhishek Rana, Punam Rattan
publish: 2025 7th International Symposium on Advanced Electrical and Communication Technologies (ISAECT)
abstract: Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) have been considered two of the essential branches of Artificial Intelligence (AI) that are transforming the approach to weed detection. There are some techniques to control weeds, such as traditional and automatic weed detection. Traditional weed control techniques include manual, chemical, and mechanical methods however, recent studies have focused on developing automated detection systems that utilize image processing along with morphological and texture characteristics.
