However, environmental conditions and biological variation continue to limit detection precision, but successful weed control is crucial to achieve maximum crop production and encourage sustainable agriculture. The objective of this paper is to conduct a review of various models used for weed detection techniques, concentrating on crops in the context of image classification and object detection tasks.

title:
A Differential Linear Matrix Inequality-based Approach to the Worst-Timing-Type H
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Control of Sampled-Data Systems
authors: Hae Yeon Park, Junghoon Kim, Hyung Tae Choi, Jung Hoon Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper addresses the problem of the worst-timing-type (WT-type) H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> control of linear sampled-data systems through the differential linear matrix inequality (DLMI)based approach. The WT-type H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> norm is defined as the supremum of the L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> norms of all the τ-dependent outputs for the impulse inputs occurring at the instant τ in the sampling interval [0,h). To tackle this problem, we first describe the linear sampled-data system by a hybrid linear system (HLS) and establish a performance analysis framework based on DLMIs and linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). The analysis framework is further extended to an optimal controller synthesis procedure for minimizing the WT-type H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> norm. Finally, a numerical simulation is given to validate the theoretical results and demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Development and Evaluation of Television Media-Based Educational Game Framework for Materials Science and Engineering Education
authors: Aroba Saleem, Idris Jeelani
abstract: Digital game-based learning (DGBL) has emerged as a promising method for improving student engagement and learning in STEM education. However, many educational games are designed as serious games, focusing less on engaging elements. Furthermore, DGBL has remained unexplored in the context of materials science and engineering. This study develops and evaluates a novel framework, television media-based educational game (TMEG). The study hypothesizes that integrating elements that make television series engaging into educational games can significantly enhance the learning experience. The study explored: 1) how to integrate TV media elements into educational games and 2) the effect of such integration on learning outcomes. The proposed three-layered TMEG framework includes: an input layer combining MSE content with narrative/design elements from student-preferred TV series; a game cycle layer enabling iterative judgment-behavior-feedback loops that transition students from declarative to applied knowledge; and an outcome layer targeting behavioral, emotional, and cognitive engagement, fostering improved content understanding. A pilot game was developed using the TMEG framework and evaluated with 96 undergraduate students. Data were collected through pre-/post-tests, the system usability scale (SUS), and qualitative feedback. Results showed a statistically significant improvement in test scores (from 74% to 89%) with topic-level scores indicating the highest gains in concepts involving multistep reasoning. The mean SUS score of 76.5 and qualitative feedback indicated strong usability. TMEG offers a novel approach to engineering education by embedding conceptually rigorous content within familiar and engaging media-based narratives. It shows strong potential to improve STEM learning outcomes, particularly in MSE.

title: Design of a Low Power Leaky Integrate-and-Fire Neuron Circuit Using a Memristor Emulator
authors: Amel Neifar, Imen Barraj, Mohamed Masmoudi
abstract: This paper presents the design and simulation of a Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) neuron circuit based on a zero-power consumption memristor emulator. The proposed architecture aims to reproduce the temporal dynamics of biological neurons while maintaining compactness and low power consumption in CMOS technology. The memristor emulator is used as a variable resistive element in the leaky branch of the neuron, providing adaptive leakage characteristics that emulate synaptic plasticity effects. The circuit was designed and simulated using a standard CMOS 180 nm process under a 1.8 V supply voltage. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed neuron exhibits controllable firing frequency and tunable threshold behavior, making it suitable for neuromorphic computing applications such as event-driven sensing and edge AI systems.

title: Routing Guidance for Emerging Transportation Systems with Improved Dynamic Trip Equity
authors: Ting Bai, Anni Li, Gehui Xu, Christos G. Cassandras, Andreas A. Malikopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper presents a dynamic routing guidance system that optimizes route recommendations for individual vehicles in an emerging transportation system while enhancing travelers’ trip equity. We develop a framework to quantify trip quality and equity in dynamic travel environments, providing new insights into how routing guidance influences equity in road transportation. Our approach enables real-time routing by incorporating both monitored and anticipated traffic congestion. We provide conditions that ensure perfect trip equity for all travelers in a free-flow network. Simulation studies on 1,000 vehicles traversing an urban road network in Boston demonstrate that our method improves trip equity by approximately 11.4% compared to the shortest-route strategy. In addition, the results reveal that our approach redistributes travel costs across vehicle types through route optimization, contributing to a more equitable transportation system.

title: Temporal Topic Modeling and Multi-Topic Inference- A Bibliometric Analysis of Methods and Applications
authors: Ketaki Bhaskar-Mali, Kavitha Rani Paramsivan, Surabhi R. Palkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Knowledge Economy (ICCIKE)
abstract: This paper presents a Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) grounded bibliometric survey of temporal topic modeling and document-level multi-topic inference. Despite rapid method growth, the field lacks a consolidated, reproducible map with normalized evaluation and clear cross-domain comparability. Using a dual-reviewer protocol across IEEE Xplore, Scopus, Web of Science, and ACM Digital Library (last search 2025-09-14), the review conducts quality appraisal, taxonomy synthesis, science mapping, and narrative synthesis with random-effects meta-analysis when metrics align. The protocol records timeslice granularity, alignment strategies, preprocessing, and vocabulary drift handling, and normalizes evaluation nomenclature. Evidence is organized across LDA/DTM, ETM/CTM, BER Topic, and dynamic embedding families and cataloged using coherence by Normalized Pointwise Mutual Information (NPMI), topic stability, topic diversity, alignment quality, and human intruder accuracy. The synthesis indicates that reported performance and mixture reliability are sensitive to preprocessing, alignment, and evaluation choices; stability across resampling and time is as critical as coherence; contextualized models often increase coherence yet may reduce temporal smoothness without explicit alignment; and adding human judgment frequently reshuffles model rankings. Coverage spans time-stamped benchmarks such as 20 Newsgroups temporal variants, Reuters RCV1/RCV2, arXiv and PubMed abstracts, social or news streams, and parliamentary and legal texts. The review delivers a taxonomy, a science map, and a standardized reporting and replication template. These outputs help researchers and practitioners design, evaluate, and compare temporal topic models more reliably across datasets and domains.

title: Best Practices Worldwide in Managing Variable Renewable Energy Forecasting: A review
authors: Karan Sareen, Bijaya Ketan Panigrahi, Kannan Balaraman, Tushar Shikhola, Arun Kumar Choudhary, Ravi Nath Tripathi, Vivek Pandey
abstract:
He Inherently Variable and Weather-dependent nature of electricity generation from solar photovoltaic (PV) and wind power systems poses a significant operational challenge to modern power systems undergoing the clean energy transition. Output from these resources is subject to unpredictable fluctuations driven by meteorological conditions, particularly wind speed and solar irradiance. This intermittency differentiates these resources from dispatchable conventional generation and necessitates the development of robust forecasting tools to maintain system reliability and operational efficiency. As the penetration of variable renewable energy (VRE) increases, accurate short-term and day-ahead forecasting becomes critical for grid stability, unit commitment, economic dispatch, and ancillary services planning. Over the past two decades, countries with high VRE integration have accumulated extensive experience in the development and deployment of forecasting methodologies. A wide range of forecasting models, techniques, and institutional frameworks have been tested and refined, resulting in the emergence of internationally recognized practices. However, it is noted that like electricity demand forecasting, there is no one-size-fits-all approach in VRE forecasting, and hence, VRE forecasting must be tailored to specific system characteristics and regional conditions.

This article synthesizes global experiences in the design, implementation, and institutional administration of VRE forecasting systems. It aims to provide a structured overview of the methodologies adopted across jurisdictions and distill best practices that support the reliable and cost-effective integration of wind and solar resources into power systems.

title: Identification of Clinical Significance of Genetic Variants Using LightGBM Blended with Attention Mechanism
authors: Soumili Saha, Soumyajit Pramanik, Soham Paul, Sougata Daw, Sayandip Bhattacharyya, Proshanta Sarkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Digital Innovations for Sustainable Solutions (ICDISS)
abstract: Accurately identifying clinical significance from a person's genetic data is a notable initiative in the advancement of personalized healthcare and early diagnosis. This study introduces an intelligent machine learning technique blended with gradient boosting and attention mechanism to analyze genetic mutations and predict the different labels of clinical significance. The dataset is taken from ClinVar, a trusted database containing detailed information on large-scale genetic variants. The proposed approach, called the LightGBM blended with Attention mechanism, analyzes the genetic data by learning the feature importance responsible for each mutation. This approach is effective at recognizing subtle, complex patterns that might otherwise go unnoticed. The proposed technique effectively recognized mutation labels and obtained 93.75% accuracy, 0.8728 precision, 0.8580 recall, and a f1 score of 0.8643. The results produced by the proposed method are promising. The suggested methodology offers a quick, precise, and adaptable way of classifying genetic mutations, which could be beneficial for making precise diagnoses of clinical significance, which in turn will help the treatment of individual patients.

title: On-policy Safe Reinforcement Learning under Input Saturation and State Constraints for Nonlinear Discrete Time Systems
authors: Satya Marthi, Mayank S Jha, Soha Kanso, Jean-Christophe Ponsart, Didier Theilliol
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: This paper proposes an on-policy Policy Iteration (PI) safe reinforcement learning (RL) framework for control of nonlinear discrete-time control-affine systems with input saturation constraints, ensuring safety throughout exploration and learning phases. This work emphasizes the importance of exploration noise while also addressing the challenges resulting from the conflict between control input saturation and exploration. Against the typically adopted off-policy PI based approaches for safe RL, our approach proposes on-policy PI algorithm under input saturation to iteratively learn the optimal control policy. To ensure safety during the exploration phase, where the high magnitude of exploration noise could compromise system safety, a so called fall-back policy is proposed and incorporated. This paper also develops novel theoretical guarantees on the convergence to optimality under safety restrictions and evaluates the effectiveness through simulation studies, comparing its performance against the traditional Quadratic Programming based Control Lyapunov and Control Barrier function (QP-CLF-CBF) approach.

title: A Convex Optimization Approach to Sensor Placement Subject to Correlated Observations
authors: Maciej Patan, Dariusz Uciński
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: A fast computational technique is proposed for sensor location maximizing the parameter estimation accuracy for spatiotemporal processes in the presence of correlated measurement noise. In the setting of a linearized Bayesian formulation incorporating prior information about the parameters, a general concave design criterion is utilized to quantify the anticipated estimation accuracy. This design criterion is maximized by selecting a best subset of gauged sites from among a given and possibly very large finite set of candidate sites. To circumvent the inherent combinatorial nature of this problem combined with the correlation structure of the errors, a convex relaxation is proposed here, which results from the decomposition of the covariance kernel into the sum of a positive definite matrix and a scalar multiple of the identity matrix. A relaxed problem is then formulated and solved using extremely efficient simplicial decomposition. Since the optimal relaxed solution is a measure on the set of candidate sites, randomization is used to convert it into a nearly optimal sensor configuration. Simulation experiments regarding a process of induction heating are reported to validate the presented approach.

title: Uniformity Analysis of Frequency Regulation for Grid-Following and Grid-Forming Wind Turbines and Distributed Cooperative Frequency Control for Hybrid Wind Farms
authors: Hongyu Zhou, Yongxin Xiong, Wei Yao, Cheng Wang, Gen Li, Tianshu Bi
abstract: Large numbers of grid-connected wind farms challenge frequency stability. Hybrid wind farms (HWFs) with both grid-following (GFL) and grid-forming (GFM) wind turbines (WTs) are better adapted to wide-ranging changes in grid state. However, the frequency support capability of each wind turbine in an HWF depends on factors like wind speed and control type. Current controls do not fully exploit the grid frequency support potential of each WT in different states. Hence, this paper first analyzes the frequency regulation characteristics of GFL WTs and virtual synchronous generator (VSG)-based GFM WTs, revealing the uniformity between them. Furthermore, a distributed cooperative frequency control (DCFC) for HWFs is proposed to improve grid frequency stability. DCFC uses a leaderless consistency algorithm to allocate the output active power of each wind turbine according to the state of the different WTs. Additionally, the adaptive optimisation feature of DCFC adjusts the frequency support coefficients of the wind turbines in real time as their rotor kinetic energy varies, improving the safety of the WTs. Finally, the GFL and GFM frequency regulation uniformity theory and the DCFC are comprehensively verified. The results show that DCFC improves the security of the WTs and enhances the frequency support capability compared to centralised control.

title: Leveraging AI in Regulating Insurance Fraud
authors: Shikha Awasthi, Harsh Purohit, Ved Prakash Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Knowledge Economy (ICCIKE)
abstract: The insurance industry is one of the sectors in India that are being increasingly transformed by Artificial Intelligence (AI) to automate operations, enhance the assessment of risks, accelerate the quickly processing of claims, and identify fraudulent activities more accurately. Although this is in its initial phases in India, efforts of NITI Aayog and IRDAI underscore its increased relevance in fighting insurance fraud. In this paper, the role of AI, challenges, and remedies of enhancing fraud control in the insurance sector have been reviewed.

title: Generative AI-Based Hypothesis Generation for Self-Evolving Machine Learning in Research Applications
authors: Damodhara Reddy Palavali, Suneetha Pothireddy
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Emerging Trends in Engineering and Computing (ETECOM)
abstract: The hypothesis synthesis framework, based on Generative AI, is proposed in the study to address self-evolving machine learning as an application that is needed in research contexts where continual adaptation and tradeoffs between training progress are essential. The suggested system is unlike the traditional static models in the sense that it includes a closed loop of observe, generate, evaluate and act so that iterative correction to the system is feasible with the changing data and performance of the system. The framework utilizes hybrid generative processes in advancing specific hypotheses, which are then critically appraised on the basis of multi-objective premises comprising classification accuracy, minority class recall and computing efficiency. Observations of hypothesis that surpass the acceptance criterion are advanced to be the new foundation models thereby guaranteeing adaptive enhancement.We performed an example of the methodology by running a 10-iteration distributed assessment on the Adult Income data with the nodes simultaneously training and testing hypothesis under a federated-like scheme. Findings demonstrate that results consistently gain over the base, logistic regression model with feature selection-based hypotheses scoring a +3.83 percentage point accuracy pick up and a +35.29 percentage point minorities recall lift, which is maintained, in all iterations. The methodology is also designed to guarantee domain specific flexibility, decision-making transparency, and effective resource consumption, serving the current shortage of sustained adaptation, hypothesis-based research, and benchmarking of generative Artificial intelligence systems. This framework gives both a scalable and repeatable process of implementing self-evolution on various, concrete research and industrial settings.

title: A Machine Learning-Based Framework for Real-Time Malicious Node Detection in VANETs
authors: Rashmi Priyadarshini, Renu Bahuguna, Shashi Prakash Dwivedi, Aryender Singh, Chitransh Bose, Baker Karim
publish: 2025 7th International Symposium on Advanced Electrical and Communication Technologies (ISAECT)
abstract: It is essential to modern intelligent transportation systems that vehicles and infrastructure can communicate in real-time through vehicle ad-hoc networks (VANETs). A VANET's dynamic and decentralised nature makes it highly vulnerable to security threats such as Sybil attacks and black holes. Using machine learning, this paper develops a real-time adaptive framework for detecting malicious nodes in VANETs. The proposed system effectively identifies anomalous behaviour even under evolving network conditions using adaptive random forests (ARFs) and k-nearest neighbours (KNNs). Simulated datasets have been evaluated using simulation environments such as SUMO and NS-3. Using this model, VANET environments can be secured in real-time, even under high attack intensities, demonstrating a scalable and efficient solution.

title: Photonics Terahertz Dual-Band Anti-Jamming Integrated Sensing and Communication System Empowered by Permutation Frequency Hopping
authors: Ningyuan Zhong, Wenlin Bai, Xihua Zou, Jiongbin Deng, Fengwei Liu, Biao Ge, Jincong Hu, Yaoping Wu, Tao He, Wei Pan, Lianshan Yan
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) has emerged as a favorable candidate to support the forthcoming 6G applications. However, conventional ISAC systems, constrained to operate within predetermined frequency ranges, remain highly susceptible to narrowband, fixed-frequency jamming, which poses significant challenges in hostile electromagnetic environments. In this paper, a dual-band anti-jamming ISAC system operating in the D-band is proposed using permutation frequency hopping (PFH). Compared with traditional single-band frequency hopping spread spectrum systems, the dual-band PFH system exploits frequency diversity, maintaining sensing and communication even when one sub-band is jammed. Besides, it possesses superiorities of non-repeating adjacent frequencies and zero maximum out-of-phase Hamming autocorrelation, thereby enhancing anti-jamming robustness and reducing the probability of signal interception by hostile receivers. By leveraging the opposite-phase characteristic of linear frequency modulation-orthogonal frequency division multiplexing signal, the low-cost self-coherent communication receiver is realized. The dual-band PFH system reduces the functional interruption probability under various broadband noise jamming of 32.22%, 61.72% and 83.27%, respectively. In the sensing receiver, the identification of five interference types is realized by dual-band signatures. Finally, the coherent fusion processing enables a large equivalent bandwidth resolution and thus an enhanced spectral efficiency. In experiments, a dual-band signal centered at 132 GHz is generated. A data rate of ∼470 Mbit/s and an equivalent range resolution of 1.94 cm are achieved. By processing simulated echoes, the two-dimensional imaging resolution of ∼1.875 cm × ∼1.99 cm is obtained. The proposed scheme offers a promising solution for anti-jamming ISAC system in complex electromagnetic environments.

title: Player Authentication in Fighting Games using Controller Operation Dynamics
authors: Takeshi Kawamoto, Maharage Nisansala Sevwandi Perera, Franziska Zimmer, Ryosuke Kobayashi, Mhd Irvan, Rie Shigetomi Yamaguchi
publish: 2025 Thirteenth International Symposium on Computing and Networking Workshops (CANDARW)
abstract: Player authentication is crucial for preserving the integrity of esports competitions, yet current measures cannot entirely prevent impersonation via collusion. While behavioral biometrics provide a promising complementary solution, their application to fighting games, characterized by rapid, skillful controller inputs, remains underexplored. This study proposes a player authentication method for fighting games that applies keystroke-authentication principles to controller input dynamics. We conducted experiments using 99 matches from nine professional players of Street Fighter 6 and demonstrated the effectiveness of our approach, showing an area under the precision-recall curve (PR-AUC) of $\mathbf{7 5. 7 \%}$. Furthermore, our analysis revealed that the biometric signal is highly context-dependent: in-combat data yielded higher performance than idle-time data. These findings validate the applicability of keystroke-dynamics principles to controller dynamics and establish an interpretable baseline.

title: Scalable Trajectory Planning for Multi-Agent Systems Using Continuum Mechanics and Bernstein Polynomials
authors: Maxwell Hammond, Gage MacLin, Amirreza F. Golestaneh, Venanzio Cichella
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: When tackling the issue of scalability in trajectory planning for large numbers of agents, generation of continuous surfaces from partial differential equation solutions has become increasingly popular. In this work, a framework borrowing from principles of continuum dynamics is proposed for scalable trajectory generation of multi-agent systems. The problem is presented as an optimal control problem (OCP), transcribed to a nonlinear programming (NLP) problem with Bernstein polynomials, which gives a solution as a time-dependent solid. This solution inherently guarantees inter-agent collision avoidance and leverages the unique properties of the Bernstein basis to ensure adherence to constraints including obstacle collision avoidance.

title: Real-Time 204 Tb/s Optical Wireless Connectivity Enabled by WDM/MDM and 800G Optical Modules
authors: Songyuan Hu, Yunhong Liu, Peng Sun, Xumeng Liu, Juncheng Fang, Ting Lei, Shupeng Li, Ji Wang, Yuru Tang, Linbojie Huang, Xu Zhang, Zichen Liu, Wei Sun, Zhixue He, Chao Li
abstract: The combination of wavelength division multiplexing (WDM) and mode division multiplexing (MDM) is a promising route to drastically increase the capacity of optical wireless communication (OWC). However, the development of mode multiplexers/demultiplexers (MUXs/DeMUXs) that concurrently deliver low insertion loss and low inter-mode crosstalk over a wide optical band remains challenging. Moreover, while 800G coherent optical modules are commercially available, their use in ultra-high-capacity OWC systems lacks experimental validation. To address these issues, this work presents an integrated solution employing a novel multi-channel, MIMO-free spatial mode MUX/DeMUX based on multi-plane light conversion (MPLC) alongside commercial 800G coherent transponders for ultra-high capacity OWC system. This setup enables the first demonstration of a real-time OWC system with a net data rate of 204 Tb/s. The implemented mode MUX/DeMUX exhibits >27.91dB isolation and power losses below 18.91dB (C6T-band) and 18.71dB (L6T-band), enabling MIMO-free operation. These results provide critical insights for future ultra-high-capacity OWC systems.

title: Robustly Invertible Nonlinear Dynamics and the BiLipREN: Contracting Neural Models with Contracting Inverses
authors: Yurui Zhang, Ruigang Wang, Ian R. Manchester
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: We study the invertibility of nonlinear dynamical systems from the perspective of contraction and incremental stability analysis and propose a new invertible recurrent neural model: the BiLipREN. In particular, we consider a nonlinear state space model to be robustly invertible if an inverse exists with a state space realisation, and both the forward model and its inverse are contracting, i.e. incrementally exponentially stable, and Lipschitz, i.e. have bounded incremental gain. This property of bi-Lipschitzness implies both robustness in the sense of sensitivity to input perturbations, as well as robust distinguishability of different inputs from their corresponding outputs, i.e. the inverse model robustly reconstructs the input sequence despite small perturbations to the initial conditions and measured output. Building on this foundation, we propose a parameterization of neural dynamic models: bi-Lipschitz recurrent equilibrium networks (biLipREN), which are robustly invertible by construction. Moreover, biLipRENs can be composed with orthogonal linear systems to construct more general bi-Lipschitz dynamic models, e.g., a nonlinear analogue of minimum-phase/all-pass (inner/outer) factorization. We illustrate the utility of our proposed approach with numerical examples.

title: An IoT-based Healthcare System and Hybrid Deep Learning Model to Early Diagnose Chronic Kidney Disease
authors: M Ramamoorthy, A Manimaran, Carmel Mary Belinda M J, Gnanajeyaraman Rajaram, U Arul
publish: 2025 International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Knowledge Economy (ICCIKE)
abstract: This study has suggested an IoT-based healthcare environment with a hybrid deep learning system to facilitate the early detection of chronic kidney disease (CKD). The ultimate challenge was to create an intelligent diagnostic system that was capable of accurately labeling the status of CKD when analyzed against the set of patient data that could be gathered by IoT sensors. Complex performance measures such as accuracy, recall, precision, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F 1}$</tex>-score and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) were employed to measure the performance of the model. The trained and validated model was then based on the CKD data to reflect the real-world data situation in the healthcare sector. The outcome revealed that the accuracy of the hybrid deep learning model was 95% and overall accuracy was 0.96 of AUC, 92.5 F1-score, 92 percent of recall, and 93 percent of precision. These findings showed a striking performance of the model to accurately classify non-CKD and CKD conditions as well as reduce the number of false conclusions. Although ROC and precisionrecall curves exemplified exemplary resilience when processing unbalanced medical data, the confusion matrix demonstrated satisfactory consistency in classification, which is why the system can be considered an effective tool to detect CKD at its early stages, positively affecting the health of patients and decreasing the load on the healthcare system. In general, this paper has shown the role that hybrid deep learning models and IoT frameworks can take in the development of proactive and intelligent healthcare systems.

title: Machine Learning Techniques for Lung Image Enhancement and Detection: A Survey
authors: Vivek Kumar, Amit Ranjan, Vineet Shekher, Manjeet, Ashanand, Shyambir Singh Poonia, R Narendra Rao
publish: 2025 7th International Symposium on Advanced Electrical and Communication Technologies (ISAECT)
abstract: Lung imaging is vital for diagnosing respiratory diseases like COPD, asthma, lung cancer and guiding treatment. However, image quality limitations (noise, low resolution, obstructing anatomy) can impede accurate interpretation. Machine learning (ML), especially deep learning, has driven advances in post-acquisition image enhancement, including denoising, super-resolution, bone suppression, and artifact removal. This review surveys traditional and ML-based enhancement methods across chest radiography, CT, and MRI. We categorize approaches these approaches as supervised, unsupervised, CNNs, GANs and transformers. A comparison is performed using performance metrics like PSNR, SSIM, Entropy, AMBE and RMSE. The data scarcity, artifacts, generalizability challenges are also highlighted. The various scope for the future research directions are also examined. Advanced enhancement post-processing can cost-effectively improve diagnostic quality, spurring many ML-based algorithms in recent years.

title: Unified IoT Framework for Smart Parking Management and EV Charging Stations
authors: Raveena R Nair, Shraddha Anand, Akansha Saha, Sreecharan S., Krish Chabbria, T. Shreeram
publish: 2025 7th International Symposium on Advanced Electrical and Communication Technologies (ISAECT)
abstract: Smart urban infrastructure demands real-time, efficient, and scalable solutions for vehicular parking and electric vehicle (EV) charging. The current paper suggests a Unified IoT Framework, which would consolidate the smart parking management and EV charging infrastructure based on a multi-layered architecture of IoT sensors, edge gateways, and cloud analytics. The system includes ultrasonic and infrared (IR) sensors to understand the occupancy of parking slots, the current and voltage sensors to track the EV charging parameters. Information is gathered using microcontrollers and handled locally on Jetson Nano edge gateways and transferred to a cloud backend via MQTT over LoRaWAN, NB-IoT, or Wi-Fi, depending on the environmental conditions. The design uses dynamic slot assignment using Q-learning, predictive pricing, and blockchain-based billing to enhance integrity and confidence to the users. An experimental analysis in a testbed of 50 parking slots and 10 EV charging stations showed that the occupancy detection accuracy could be measured at 98.2 on average, and that billing integrity and network uptime were 100.0 and 99.5 respectively. The edge processing latency was below 50 ms which confirms the responsiveness of the system. The integrated platform also realized an efficient load balancing of energy with 23.5% of the charging energy coming out of solar panels demonstrating its sustainability. The findings have validated the fact that the suggested framework is strong, flexible, and prepared to implement in reality in cities and suburbs.

title: Grey-Box AI for Cement-Free Stabilization: Interpretable UCS Prediction and Design Rules for Xanthan–PPF Clays
authors: Abolfazl Baghbani, Firas Daghistani, Hossam Abuel-Naga, Mohammad Mahdi Shalchian
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Emerging Trends in Engineering and Computing (ETECOM)
abstract: We develop a grey-box framework for predicting unconfined compressive strength (UCS) of a cement-free, xanthan gum (XG)–polypropylene fibre (PPF) stabilized low-plasticity clay. Using 108 UCS tests (factors: curing time, PPF, XG, dry density, water-to-xanthan mass ratio W/XG), we benchmark multiple linear regression (MLR), classification-and-regression trees (CART), and symbolic-regression genetic programming (GP). Two interpretable surrogates are produced: (i) a closed-form GP equation (with train-set min– max normalization) and (ii) a threshold-based CART design tree. On the held-out test set, GP achieved R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.98 (RMSE 38 kPa; MAE 32 kPa), outperforming CART (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>=0.94; RMSE 66; MAE 55) and MLR. Across models, dry density and curing time dominate, with higher UCS at low W/XG, modest XG (≈1–5%), and PPF ≈ 0.5%. By embedding mechanistic priors (gelation, fibre crack-bridging, curing maturation, compaction) into model choice and constraints, the framework yields transparent, field-ready guidance while reducing reliance on high-CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> binders. The models are validated for a single CL soil; broader use should respect this domain or be re-calibrated with additional soils.

title: Almost Sure Convergence in Feedback Optimization via Stochastic Timescale Separation
authors: Guido Carnevale, Giuseppe Notarstefano
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: In this paper, we study discrete-time feedback optimization in stochastic scenarios. Specifically, we consider a discrete-time stochastic nonlinear system where the goal is to optimize its steady-state performance while simultaneously controlling it. Moreover, in our framework, we deal with packet losses in the communication between the controller and the physical system. To address these challenges, we propose a gradient-based controller embedding sample-and-hold mechanisms to handle packet losses. We analyze the resulting stochastic closed-loop system through the lens of stochastic timescale separation. This perspective allows us to establish the almost sure global asymptotic convergence of the closed-loop system to a set in which first-order optimality conditions of the underlying nonconvex optimization problem are satisfied. Finally, we provide numerical simulations to support our theoretical findings.

title: Multi-Source Information Fusion for Recognition of Typical Paved-Road Features
authors: Feiyang Xu, Xinjie Zhang, Xulong Jin, Tiegang Hu, Sheng Lu
publish: 2025 12th International Conference on Dependable Systems and Their Applications (DSA)
abstract: As vehicle intelligence advances, effectively exploiting heterogeneous onboard data to recognize features of paved roads is foundational to ensuring handling stability and ride comfort. Currently, conventional single-source methods are constrained by modality-specific limitations and struggle to balance accuracy with real-time performance. This paper proposes the Multi-Source Information Fusion Estimation Framework (MSIF-EF) that leverages digital map priors, onboard vision, and vehicle-response information to estimate typical paved-road features. The proposed framework establishes a closed-loop pipeline-prior acquisition, online verification, and information updating–in which map priors condition the estimator's initial state; onboard vision and vehicle dynamic responses cross-validate recognition in real time to correct prior biases; and a writeback mechanism enables dynamic correction and continual updating of map data. Simulation studies show that, with map priors available, the proposed MSIF-EF markedly shortens convergence time and improves recognition accuracy relative to dynamics-based estimators; when priors are missing or degraded, it still sustains high accuracy over single-modality baselines while updating the map online.

title: SeparateGen: Semantic Component-based 3D Character Generation from Single Images
authors: Dong-Yang Li, Yi-Long Liu, Zi-Xian Liu, Yan-Pei Cao, Meng-Hao Guo, Shi-Min Hu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Creating detailed 3D characters from a single image remains challenging due to the difficulty in separating semantic components during generation. Existing methods often produce entangled meshes with poor topology, hindering downstream applications like rigging and animation. We introduce SeparateGen, a novel framework that generates high-quality 3D characters by explicitly reconstructing them as distinct semantic components (e.g., body, clothing, hair, shoes) from a single, arbitrary-pose image. SeparateGen first leverages a multi-view diffusion model to generate consistent multi-view images in a canonical Apose. Then, a novel component-aware reconstruction model, SC-LRM, conditioned on these multi-view images, adaptively decomposes and reconstructs each component with high fidelity. To train and evaluate SeparateGen, we contribute SC-Anime, the first large-scale dataset of 7,580 anime-style 3D characters with detailed component-level annotations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that SeparateGen significantly outperforms stateof- the-art methods in both reconstruction quality and multiview consistency. Furthermore, our component-based approach effectively resolves mesh entanglement issues, enabling seamless rigging and asset reuse. SeparateGen thus represents a step towards generating high-quality, application-ready 3D characters from a single image. The SC-Anime dataset and our code will be publicly released.

title: QFedPhish: A Quantum-Inspired Federated Learning Approach for Detecting AI-Generated Phishing Attacks
authors: Abdul Malik, Saeed Mian Qaisar
abstract: Advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) offer opportunities but have also contributed to the emergence of AIgenerated attacks, escalating the complexity and scale of modern cyber threats. These attacks generate serious concerns for the traditional security systems in maintaining accuracy, privacy, false-positive control, and resilience in modern distributed environments. To cope with these concerns, this paper proposes QFedPhish, a quantum-inspired federated learning approach designed to identify and detect AI-generated phishing attacks. A combination of real-world phishing logs with synthetically generated large language model-based phishing attempts is built as a representative dataset. This data is then transformed through a quantum-inspired feature encoder, where random Fourier features and tensor-network compression capture subtle stylometric and structural cues that distinguish phishing content from legitimate content. Next, each participating client locally trains a lightweight classifier on the resulting embeddings, enabling model adaptation to heterogeneous environments without exposing raw data. Finally, model updates are aggregated using federated learning enhanced with differential privacy and resilient aggregation mechanisms. It mitigates risks of data leakage and poisoning attacks. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that QFedPhish consistently outperforms the best benchmark models, achieving gains of 0.10% in accuracy, 0.33% in precision, 0.41% in F1-score, 0.61% in AUC, along with reducing communication overhead by 3.89% and improving convergence speed by 3.66%.

title: Reply to “Comments on Near-Field Prediction in Complex Environment Based on Phaseless Scanned Fields and Machine Learning”
authors: Dong-Hao Han, Xing-Chang Wei, Yong-Liang Zhang
abstract: A correspondence has been published to comment on the recently published paper “Near-Field Prediction in Complex Environment Based on Phaseless Scanned Fields and Machine Learning” by (Wen et al., 2021). The correspondence points out three comments: the consistency of the multipole expansion employed, the format and interpretability of the obtained artificial neural network model, and the relative accuracy of predicted emitted fields between the modeling methods. In this correspondence, we provide our replies to the raised issues.

title: Seasonal Dependence of Topographic Effect on Mountainous Land Surface Temperature Retrieval: Insights From Landsat-8 Data
authors: Zhi-Wei He, Bo-Hui Tang, Xin-Ming Zhu, Zhao-Liang Li
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Land surface temperature (LST) is a key parameter for characterizing land–atmosphere interactions, energy balance, and ecological processes. Previous studies have incorporated topographic effects in mountainous LST (MLST) retrieval, yet systematic quantification of the seasonal magnitude of these effects remains lacking. In this study, Landsat-8 thermal infrared data are employed from the sensor's observational perspective, and representative images for spring, summer, autumn, and winter are selected across the Tibet Plateau, enabling the determination of seasonal topographic effects (ΔLST), where ΔLST refers to the difference between LST retrieved without and with consideration of topographic effects. Results indicate that ΔLST is primarily controlled by topographic factors, including small-scale self-heating parameters (SSP), sky view factor (SVF), and land surface emissivity (LSE). Among the seasons, topographic effect is most pronounced in summer, with ΔLST exceeding 8 K in rugged areas with low emissivity. ΔLST exhibits clear dependence on slope and aspect, with south-facing slopes generally higher than north-facing slopes, and increasing with slope steepness, indicating that steep slopes are more sensitive to solar radiation. Further analysis reveals that ΔLST is positively correlated with SSP, and negatively correlated with SVF and LSE, with the strongest correlations observed in summer, suggesting that topographic radiation imbalance is the dominant mechanism controlling MLST variability. Note that when SSP is close to 1.0, SVF is close to 0.0, and LSE is close to 1.0, ΔLST is minimal, and topographic effects on LST can be neglected. Overall, the seasonal pattern of ΔLST follows the order: summer > autumn ≈ spring > winter, and a recent increasing trend in ΔLST implies enhanced thermal responses in mountainous regions under climate warming. These findings improve understanding of topographic influences on MLST retrieval and provide more reliable LST data for studies of energy balance, evapotranspiration, and ecological processes.

title: Ultrawideband Transmitting Metasurface Design and Behavior Prediction With Analytical Model of Cascade Multilayer Conductors
authors: Mengzhen Wang, Ruizhi Liu, Weijian Si, Jinxin Li, Bin Liu, Zhian Deng, Ke Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Metasurfaces have emerged as a transformative technology in modern electromagnetic (EM), yet their design is often guided by empirical approaches lacking a unified analytical framework. This article introduces an efficient method for designing multilayer resonant metasurfaces and accurately predicting their radiation coefficients. The approach relies on a 1-D parametric sweep of a single-layer conductor, enabling numerical prediction of radiation coefficients across varying interlayer spacings and substrate thicknesses. It also facilitates precise estimation of Huygens resonance positions. The method offers high predictive accuracy and significantly accelerates the identification of optimal frequency ranges and unit cell parameters, streamlining the metasurface design process. To validate the proposed technique, a focusing transmission metasurface based on a triple-layer Jerusalem cross unit cell is designed, simulated, and experimentally characterized. The metasurface demonstrates robust transmission amplitude and near-complete phase control across the 6–8-GHz band. Measurements confirm stable focusing performance with minimal focal drift over a 28.6% ultrawide bandwidth.

title: A Standalone-in-Memory Voltage Crossover-Based Assist Switching Circuit for Reliable and Efficient Process Tracking Memory Vmin Improvement in Intel 18A-RibbonFET Technology
authors: Saroj Satapathy, Amlan Ghosh, John Riley, Jalal Quadri, Jaydeep Kulkarni, Feroze Merchant
abstract: Advanced CMOS memory requires voltage biasing assist techniques to achieve low operating voltages (Vmin), which must be deactivated at higher voltages for high electric field reliability. Centralized Power Management Unit (PMU) control signals face timing synchronization and process tracking challenges when distributed across cores to activate assist circuits in various SRAM arrays, limiting their effectiveness. This restricts the power and area benefits that could be gained from an in-situ, memory circuit-assist enable/disable mechanism. To address this, we propose a novel voltage crossover-based memory assist switching circuit implemented in Intel 18A-RibbonFET technology featuring backside power delivery. Its 150X area efficiency enables independent placement within memory blocks, offering 19% array-level power and 17% performance improvements. Silicon measurements show tight variation control and strong simulation correlation.

title: Continuous-time Data-driven Barrier Certificate Synthesis
authors: Luke Rickard, Alessandro Abate, Kostas Margellos
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: We consider the problem of verifying safety for continuous-time dynamical systems. Developing upon recent advancements in data-driven verification, we use only a finite number of sampled trajectories to learn a barrier certificate, namely a function which verifies safety. We train a safety-informed neural network to act as this certificate, with an appropriately designed loss function to encompass the safety conditions. In addition, we provide probabilistic generalisation guarantees from discrete samples of continuous trajectories, to unseen continuous ones. Numerical results demonstrate the efficacy of our approach and contrast it with related results in the literature.

title:
System Identification for Virtual Sensor-Based Model Predictive Control: Application to a 2-DoF Direct-Drive Robotic Arm
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Kosei Tsuji, Ichiro Maruta, Kenji Fujimoto, Tomoyuki Maeda, Yoshihisa Tamase, Tsukasa Shinohara
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: Nonlinear Model Predictive Control (NMPC) offers a powerful approach for controlling complex nonlinear systems, yet faces two key challenges. First, accurately modeling nonlinear dynamics remains diﬃcult. Second, variables directly related to control objectives often cannot be directly measured during operation. Although high-cost sensors can measure these variables during model development, their use in practical deployment is typically infeasible. To overcome these limitations, we propose a Predictive Virtual Sensor Identification (PVSID) framework that leverages temporary high-cost sensors during the modeling phase to create virtual sensors for NMPC implementation. We validate PVSID on a Two-Degree-of-Freedom (2-DoF) direct-drive robotic arm with complex joint interactions. The tip position is measured using a motion capture system during modeling, while encoders and an Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) are utilized in NMPC. Experimental results show that our NMPC with identified virtual sensors achieves precise tip trajectory tracking without requiring the motion capture system during operation. PVSID offers a practical solution for implementing optimal control in nonlinear systems where the measurement of key variables is constrained by cost or operational limitations.

title: SU-FTD2: Transformer-Driven Brain Tumor Imaging Framework using Explainable AI for Consumer Applications
authors: Anita Murmu, Naween Kumar, Surbhi B. Khan, Eid Albalawi, Ahlam Almusharraf, Awad Albalawi
abstract: In the clinic, brain tumor detection and semantic segmentation are critical tasks in medical image analysis, particularly in magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), which assists clinicians in diagnosing and monitoring tumor progression. However, convolutional models struggle with long-range information due to limited kernel sizes, which affects the precision of tumor segmentation, especially for tumors of varying sizes. On the other hand, transformer architecture excels at capturing long-range dependencies across domains such as computer vision. This inspired the adoption of vision transformer-based architectures for improved medical image analysis. This study presents SUFTD2, a novel segmentation framework that combines (Swin UNET Transformers) Swin UNETR with a finetuned Detectron2 model to detect and segment brain tumors precisely. Swin UNETR treats brain tumor segmentation as a sequence-to-sequence tumor prediction task, projecting multi-modal image data into a 1D sequence for processing by a hierarchical Swin UNETR encoder. This encoder extracts features at multiple resolutions using shifted windows for self-attention computation. A finetuned model from the Detectron2 model zoo is also used to detect tumor locations and regions. Our suggested framework supports continuous, decentralized medical monitoring by bridging AI-driven segmentation with connected healthcare infrastructure. It incorporates explainable AI (XAI) methods, including LIME and SHAP, to highlight tumor regions that influence predictions, thus improving clinical trust and interpretability. Using XAI and consumer-deployable technologies, the framework advances the accessibility and transparency of brain tumor diagnostics enabled by ubiquitous consumer electronics, aligning with next-generation connected healthcare goals. The proposed XAI-integrated Swin UNETR framework, which leverages consumer electronics for deployment, makes more advanced brain tumor diagnostics available and transparent. The proposed scheme has been tested on the BraTS2020 dataset. We use several performance evaluation matrices to evaluate the experimental outcomes of the proposed scheme. The proposed approach demonstrates outperformance compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: State-of-Grid-Based SoC Balancing and AC Coupling Control for DC Microgrids
authors: Ömer Ekin, Max Leuthaeusser, Giovanni De Carne, Veit Hagenmeyer
abstract: The shift towards renewable energy has increased interest in dc microgrids as a promising integration solution. However, managing power-sharing, state-of-charge (SoC) balancing, and reliable ac coupling without communication remains challenging, necessitating advanced control methods. This article introduces a novel state-of-grid-based control for dc microgrids, enabling communication-free power-sharing and SoC balancing across battery systems, even with significant line resistances, while supporting synergistic ac coupling. Each battery locally projects its SoC into a small voltage offset around the nominal dc bus level; the resulting bus voltage therefore mirrors the average SoC of the entire microgrid. By using an analogous mapping for ac frequency, a single voltage–frequency metric unifies dc and ac domains. A small-signal Lyapunov analysis proves local exponential stability under realistic parameter spreads. The controller is implemented on a laboratory microgrid comprising two battery emulators, photovoltaic generation, programmable loads, and a Silicon Carbide interlink converter. Hardware results in islanded and grid-connected modes confirm voltage regulation, SoC equalization, and seamless power exchange.

title: Using Ramp Functions to solve LP-based MPC
authors: Morten Hovd, Giorgio Valmorbida
publish: 2025 IEEE 64th Conference on Decision and Control (CDC)
abstract: A new solution strategy, utilizing ramp functions, is proposed for solving LP problems arising in Model Predictive Control. The solution strategy can take a general LP formulation, and avoids the increase in optimization variables resulting from converting the LP problem into standard form. Unlike the simplex method, there is no need to find an initial feasible solution. Numerical experiments demonstrate a significant increase in solution speed compared to the previously proposed ramp-based Simplex [1], and compares favorably to a state-of-the-art commercial solver like CPLEX [2] for small to moderately sized problems.

title: Lightweight multi-sensor information fusion framework for robust Monorail Transit Beam-Joint Impact Detection
authors: Yuanjin Ji, Jian Li, Lihui Ren, Hongren Gong, Yuenjian Chen
abstract: Beam–joint discontinuities in straddle-type monorail tracks induce periodic vertical impacts that degrade ride comfort and long-term safety. This paper proposes a lightweight multi-sensor fusion framework that performs real-time beam–joint detection and impact early warning by combining forward-view images with bogie speed. We develop an edge-deployable model, YOLOBJ, obtained by simplifying the YOLOv10 head to a single scale, streamlining the neck with parallel feature fusion, and introducing a Multi-Receptive-Field Fusion Layer. A constrained evolutionary neural architecture search (LEANAS) further optimizes channel widths. The final network contains 0.33M parameters, runs at an average 3.2ms per frame on an NVIDIA Jetson AGX Orin, and achieves mAP50–95 = 0.785 on real-vehicle data. Field experiments with operating trains demonstrate that the proposed image+speed fusion provides predictive perception and outperforms a single-acceleration threshold baseline: recall increases by 8.9%, F1 by 5.3%, precision by 1.8%, and accuracy by 4.7%. The framework offers a practical solution for on-board deployment, supporting improved ride quality and enabling intelligent damping/control strategies for monorail systems.

title: Blockchain-Driven ESG Reporting: Enhancing Stakeholder Engagement and an Antidote for Greenwashing
authors: Richard Wiputra, David Sundaram, Ghazwan Hassna
publish: 2025 11th International HCI and UX Conference in Indonesia (CHIuXiD)
abstract: Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) reporting and rating practices continue to face persistent challenges related to data transparency, reliability, and stakeholder trust. Existing processes are frequently fragmented and susceptible to greenwashing, limiting their effectiveness in guiding responsible investment and corporate accountability. This paper proposes a blockchain-based artifact designed to enhance the integrity of ESG reporting by combining blockchain's immutability and decentralized consensus with established ESG frameworks such as GRI and MSCI. Using a design science research approach, the study develops a prototype system that automates key reporting functions through smart contracts, enabling transparent data provenance, standardized disclosures, and multi-stakeholder participation. The artifact is evaluated through a Delphi study involving experts in sustainability, information systems, and governance. The results highlight blockchain's strong potential to improve ESG data trustworthiness while emphasizing the need for scalability enhancements and strategies that support user adoption across industries. Overall, the study contributes to the information systems literature on emerging technologies for sustainability by demonstrating how decentralized ledgers can strengthen ESG reporting processes and foster greater alignment between corporate practices and global environmental and governance objectives.

title: Design and Implementation of Management Accounting System Based on Drools Rule Engine
authors: Haixiao Zhang, Lei Wang
publish: 2025 20th International Joint Symposium on Artificial Intelligence and Natural Language Processing (iSAI-NLP)
abstract: As a key support for business decision-making, the operational efficiency and flexibility of the management accounting system directly affect the timeliness and accuracy of management decisions. Traditional management accounting systems rely on manual entry of accounting vouchers, which makes it difficult to meet the real-time accounting needs of high concurrency transaction scenarios. In addition, the deep coupling between business rules and code leads to delayed response to rule changes, and the heterogeneity of multi-source data formats also exacerbates the difficulty of maintaining data consistency. In response to the above issues, this article designs and implements a management accounting system based on the Drools rule engine. The system adopts a B/S architecture and a three-layer system of “presentation layer business logic layer data access layer”, building three core subsystems of rule management, rule engine, and data processing: using Drools to achieve visual configuration and dynamic updates of accounting rules, relying on the Rete algorithm to optimize the matching efficiency between transaction data and rules, combining message queues and cross database technology to process real-time and batch transaction data, and realizing automatic generation of accounting vouchers and entries. The experimental results show that the system's single note taking time has been reduced to milliseconds, the response time for rule updates has been shortened from hours to minutes, and the accuracy of continuous operation data has reached over 99.9 %. This effectively improves the efficiency, flexibility, and data consistency of management accounting, providing reliable technical support for dynamic business scenarios of enterprises.
